Play details
The merry wiues of Windsor. Genre: Comedy. Date first published: 1602. Date first performed: 23 Apr 1597.
Chadwyck-Healey Literature on Line text, downloaded as plain text from web, checked against The Norton Facsimile: The First Folio of Shakespeare, ed. Charlton Hinman (London: Paul Hamlyn)

encodingDesc.p: The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Sir John Falstaff. Fenton; a young gentleman. Shallow; a country justice. Slender; cousin to Shallow. Ford; gentleman of Windsor. Page; gentleman of Windsor. William Page; a boy; son to Page. Sir Hugh Evans; a Welsh parson. Doctor Caius; a French physician. Host of the Garter Inn. Bardolph; follower of Falstaff. Pistol; follower of Falstaff. Nym; follower of Falstaff. Robin; page to Falstaff. Simple; servant to Slender. Rugby; servant to Doctor Caius. Mistress Ford. Mistress Page. Mistress Anne Page; her daughter. Mistress Quickly; servant to Doctor Caius. Servant Servant 1 Servant 2 Multiple speakers

div2.stage:
Enter Iustice Shallow, Slender, Sir Hugh Euans, Master
Page, Falstoffe, Bardolph, Nym, Pistoll, Anne Page,
Mistresse Ford, Mistresse Page, Simple.

sp.speaker: Shallow.
sp.p:
Sir Hugh, persuade me not: I will make a Star-Chamber
matter of it, if he were twenty Sir
Iohn Falstoffs, he shall not abuse Robert Shallow
Esquire.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: In the County of Glocester, Justice of Peace and Coram.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Aye (Cousin Slender) and Cust-alorum.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
Aye, and Rato lorum too; and a Gentleman born
(Master Parson) who writes himself Armigero, in any
Bill, Warrant, Quittance, or Obligation, Armigero.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
Aye that I do, and have done any time these three
hundred years.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
All his successors (gone before him) hath done it:
and all his Ancestors (that come after him) may: they
may give the dozen white Luces in their Coat.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: It is an old Coat.

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p:
The dozen white Louses do become an old
Coat well: it agrees well passant: It is a familiar beast to
man, and signifies Love.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
The Luse is the fresh-fish, the salt-fish, is an old
Coat.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: I may quarter (Cuz).

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: You may, by marrying.

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p: It is marring indeed, if he quarter it.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Not a whit.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p:
Yes per-lady: if he has a quarter of your coat,
there is but three Skirts for yourself, in my simple conjectures;
but that is all one: if Sir Iohn Falstaffe have
committed disparagement unto you, I am of the Church
and will be glad to do my benevolence, to make atonements
and compromises between you.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: The Council shall hear it, it is a Riot.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p:
It is not meet the Council hear a Riot: there
is no fear of God in a Riot: The Council (look you)
shall desire to hear the fear of God, and not to hear a
Riot: take your viza-ments in that.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
Ha; on my life, if I were young again, the sword
should end it.

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p:
It is better that friends is the sword, and end
it: and there is also another device in my brain, which
peradventure brings good discretions with it. There is
Anne Page, which is daughter to Master Thomas Page,
which is pretty virginity.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
Mistress Anne Page? she has brown hair, and
speaks small like a woman.

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p:
It is that very person for all the world, as just as
you will desire, and seven hundred pounds of Monies,
and Gold, and Silver, is her Grand-sire upon his deaths-bed,
(God deliver to a joyful resurrections) give, when
she is able to overtake seventeen years old. It were a
good motion, if we leave our pribbles and prabbles, and
desire a marriage between Master Abraham, and Mistress
Anne Page.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
Did her Grand-sire leave her seven hundred
pound?

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: Aye, and her father is make her a better penny.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
I know the young Gentlewoman, she has good
gifts.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p:
Seven hundred pounds, and possibilities, is
good gifts.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Well, let us see honest Mr Page: is Falstaffe there?

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p:
Shall I tell you a lie? I do despise a liar, as I
do despise one that is false, or as I despise one that is not
true: the Knight Sir Iohn is there, and I beseech you be
ruled by your well-willers: I will peat the door for Mr.
Page. What ho? God-please your house here.

sp.speaker: Mr. Page.
sp.p: Who is there?

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p:
Here is God's blessing and your friend, and Justice
Shallow, and here young Master Slender: that peradventures
shall tell you another tale, if matters grow to
your likings.

sp.speaker: Mr. Page.
sp.p:
I am glad to see your Worships well: I
thank you for my Venison Master Shallow.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
Master Page, I am glad to see you: much good
do it your good heart: I wished your Venison better, it
was ill killed: how doth good Mistress Page? and I thank
you always with my heart, la: with my heart.

sp.speaker: M. Page.
sp.p: Sir, I thank you.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Sir, I thank you: by yea, and no I do.

sp.speaker: M. Pa.
sp.p: I am glad to see you, good Master Slender.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
How does your fallow Greyhound, Sir, I heard
say he was out-run on Cotsall.

sp.speaker: M. Pa.
sp.p: It could not be judged, Sir.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: You will not confess: you will not confess.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
That he will not, it is your fault, it is your fault:
it is a good dog.

sp.speaker: M. Pa.
sp.p: A Cur, Sir.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
Sir: he is a good dog, and a fair dog, can there
be more said? he is good, and fair. Is Sir Iohn Falstaffe
here?

sp.speaker: M. Pa.
sp.p:
Sir, he is within: and I would I could do a
good office between you.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: It is spoke as a Christians ought to speak.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: He hath wronged me (Master Page.)

sp.speaker: M. Pa.
sp.p: Sir, he doth in some sort confess it.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
If it be confessed, it is not redressed; is not that
so (Mister Page?) he hath wronged me, indeed he hath, at a
word he hath: believe me, Robert Shallow Esquire, saith
he is wronged.

sp.speaker: Ma. Pa.
sp.p: Here comes Sir Iohn.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Now, Master Shallow, you will complain of me to
the King?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
Knight, you have beaten my men, killed my
dear, and broke open my Lodge.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: But not kissed your Keepers daughter?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Tut, a pin: this shall be answered.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
I will answer it strait, I have done all this:
That is now answered.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: The Council shall know this.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
It were better for you if it were known in council:
you will be laughed at.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Pauca verba; (Sir Iohn) good worts.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Good worts? good Cabbage; Slender, I broke
your head: what matter have you against me?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
Marry sir, I have matter in my head against you,
and against your cony-catching Rascals, Bardolf, Nym,
and Pistoll.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: You Banbery Cheese.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Aye, it is no matter.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p: How now, Mephostophilus?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Aye, it is no matter.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: Slice, I say; pauca, pauca: Slice, that is my humour.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Where is Simple my man? can you tell, Cousin?

sp.speaker: Eua.
sp.p:
Peace, I pray you: now let us understand: there
is three Umpires in this matter, as I understand; that is,
Master Page (fidelicet Master Page,) and there is myself,
(fidelicet myself) and the three party is (lastly, and finally)
mine Host of the Gater.

sp.speaker: Ma. Pa.
sp.p: We three to hear it, and end it between them.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p:
Very good, I will make a brief of it in my
note-book, and we will afterwards work upon the cause,
with as great discreetly as we can.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Pistoll.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p: He hears with ears.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p:
The Teuill and his Tam: what phrase is this?
he hears with ear? why, it is affectations.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Pistoll, did you pick Mister Slender's purse?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
Aye, by these gloves did he, or I would I might
never come in mine own great chamber again else, of
seven groats in mill-sixpences, and two Edward Shouelboords,
that cost me two shilling and two pence apiece
of Yead Miller: by these gloves.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Is this true, Pistoll?

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: No, it is false, if it is a pickpurse.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p:
Ha, thou mountain Foreigner: Sir Iohn, and
Master mine, I combat challenge of this Latin Bilboe:
word of denial in thy labras here; word of denial; froth,
and scum thou liest.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: By these gloves, then it was he.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p:
Be advised sir, and pass good humours: I will
say marry trap with you, if you run the nut-hooks humour
on me, that is the very note of it.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
By this hat, then he in the red face had it: for
though I cannot remember what I did when you made
me drunk, yet I am not altogether an ass.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: What say you Scarlet, and Iohn?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p:
Why sir, (for my part) I say the Gentleman had
drunk himself out of his five sentences.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: It is his five senses: fie, what the ignorance is.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p:
And being fap, sir, was (as they say) cashiered: and
so conclusions past the Careers.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
Aye, you spake in Latin then too: but it is no matter;
I will never be drunk whilst I live again, but in honest,
civil, godly company for this trick: if I be drunk, I will
be drunk with those that have the fear of God, and not
with drunken knaves.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: So God judge me, that is a virtuous mind.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
You hear all these matters denied, Gentlemen;
you hear it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Page.
sp.p:
Nay daughter, carry the wine in, we will
drink within.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: O heaven: This is Mistress Anne Page.

sp.speaker: Mr. Page.
sp.p: How now Mistress Ford?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Mistress Ford, by my troth you are very well met:
by your leave good Mistress.

sp.speaker: Mr. Page.
sp.p:
Wife, bid these gentlemen welcome: come,
we have a hot Venison pasty to dinner; Come gentlemen,
I hope we shall drink down all unkindness.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
I had rather than forty shillings I had my book
of Songs and Sonnets here: How now Simple, where
have you been? I must wait on myself, must I? you
have not the book of Riddles about you, have you?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p:
Book of Riddles? why did you not lend it to
Alice Short-cake upon All Hallows mass last, a fortnight afore
Michaelmas.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
Come Cuz, come Cuz, we stay for you: a word
with you Cuz: marry this, Cuz: there is as it were a tender,
a kind of tender, made afar off by Sir Hugh here:
do you understand me?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
Aye Sir, you shall find me reasonable; if it be so,
I shall do that that is reason.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Nay, but understand me.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: So I do Sir.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p:
Give ear to his motions; (Mr. Slender) I will
description the matter to you, if you be capacity of it.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
Nay, I will do as my Cozen Shallow says: I
pray you pardon me, he is a Justice of Peace in his Country,
simple though I stand here.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p:
But that is not the question: the question is
concerning your marriage.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Aye, there is the point Sir.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Marry is it: the very point of it, to Mistress Anne Page.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
Why if it be so; I will marry her upon any reasonable
demands.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p:
But can you affection the woman, let us command
to know that of your mouth, or of your lips: for divers
Philosophers hold, that the lips is parcel of the mouth:
therefore precisely, can you carry your good will to the maid?

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Cousin Abraham Slender, can you love her?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
I hope sir, I will do as it shall become one that
would do reason.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p:
Nay, got's Lords, and his Ladies, you must speak
possitable, if you can carry-her your desires towards her.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
That you must:
Will you, (upon good dowry) marry her?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
I will do a greater thing than that, upon your
request (Cousin) in any reason.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
Nay conceive me, conceive me, (sweet Cuz):
what I do is to pleasure you (Cuz:) can you love the
maid?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
I will marry her (Sir) at your request; but if
there be no great love in the beginning, yet Heaven
may decrease it upon better acquaintance, when we
are married, and have more occasion to know one another:
I hope upon familiarity will grow more content:
but if you say marry her, I will marry her, that I am freely
dissolved, and dissolutely.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p:
It is a very discetion answer; save the fall is in
the word, dissolutely: the ort is (according to our meaning)
resolutely: his meaning is good.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Aye: I think my Cousin meant well.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: Aye, or else I would I might be hanged (la.)

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p:
Here comes fair Mistress Anne; would I were
young for your sake, Mistress Anne.

sp.speaker: An..
sp.p:
The dinner is on the Table, my father desires
your worships company.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: I will wait on him, (fair Mistress Anne.)

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Gods blessed will: I will not be absence at the grace.

sp.speaker: An..
sp.p: Will it please your worship to come in, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: No, I thank you forsooth, heartily; I am very well.

sp.speaker: An..
sp.p: The dinner attends you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p:
I am not hungry, I thank you, forsooth: go,
Sirra, for all you are my man, go wait upon my Cousin
Shallow: a Justice of peace sometime may be beholding
to his friend, for a Man; I keep but three Men, and a
Boy yet, till my Mother be dead: but what though, yet
I live like a poor Gentleman born.

sp.speaker: An..
sp.p:
I may not go in without your worship: they
will not sit till you come.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p:
I'faith, I will eat nothing: I thank you as much as
though I did.

sp.speaker: An..
sp.p: I pray you Sir walk in.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p:
I had rather walk here (I thank you) I bruised
my shin the other day, with playing at Sword and Dagger
with a Master of Fence (three veneys for a dish of
stewed Prunes) and by my troth, I cannot abide the smell
of hot meat since. Why do your dogs bark so? be
there Bears in the Town?

sp.speaker: An..
sp.p: I think there are, Sir, I heard them talked of.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p:
I love the sport well, but I shall as soon quarrel
at it, as any man in England: you are afraid if you see the
Bear loose, are you not?

sp.speaker: An..
sp.p: Aye indeed Sir.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p:
That is meat and drink to me now: I have seen
Sackerson loose, twenty times, and have taken him by the
Chain: but (I warrant you) the women have so cried
and shrieked at it, that it past: But women indeed, cannot
abide them, they are very ill-favoured rough things.

sp.speaker: Ma. Pa.
sp.p: Come, gentle Mister Slender, come; we stay for you.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: I will eat nothing, I thank you Sir.

sp.speaker: Ma. Pa.
sp.p:
By cock and pie, you shall not choose, Sir:
come, come.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: Nay, pray you lead the way.

sp.speaker: Ma. Pa.
sp.p: Come on, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: Mistress Anne: yourself shall go first.

sp.speaker: An..
sp.p: Not I Sir, pray you keep on.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p:
Truly I will not go first: truly: I will not
do you that wrong.

sp.speaker: An..
sp.p: I pray you Sir.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p:
I will rather be unmannerly, than troublesome: you
do yourself wrong indeed.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p:
Go your ways, and ask of Doctor Caius house,
which is the way; and there dwells one Mistress Quickly;
which is in the manner of his Nurse; or his dry-Nurse; or
his Cook; or his Laundry; his Washer, and his Ringer.

sp.speaker: Si..
sp.p: Well Sir.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p:
Nay, it is better yet: give her this letter; for it is
a woman that altogethers acquaintance with Mistress Anne
Page; and the Letter is to desire, and require her to solicit
your Masters desires, to Mistress Anne Page: I pray
you be gone: I will make an end of my dinner; there is Pippins
and Cheese to come.

div2.stage: Enter Falstaffe, Host, Bardolfe, Nym, Pistoll, Page.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Mine Host of the Garter?

sp.speaker: Ho..
sp.p:
What says my Bully Rook? speak scholarly,
and wisely.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Truly mine Host; I must turn away some of my
followers.

sp.speaker: Ho..
sp.p:
Discard, (bully Hercules) cashier; let them wag;
trot, trot.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I sit at ten pounds a week.

sp.speaker: Ho..
sp.p:
Thou art an Emperor (Caesar, Kaiser and Pheazar)
I will entertain Bardolfe: he shall draw; he shall tap; said
I well (bully Hector?)

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Do so (good mine Host.

sp.speaker: Ho..
sp.p:
I have spoke: let him follow, let me see thee froth,
and live: I am at a word: follow.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Bardolfe, follow him: a Tapster is a good trade:
an old Cloak, makes a new Jerkin: a withered Serving-man,
a fresh Tapster: go, adieu.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: It is a life that I have desired: I will thrive.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p: O base hungarian wight: wilt thou the spigot wield.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: He was gotten in drink: is not the humour conceited?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
I am glad I am so acquit of this Tinderbox: his
Thefts were too open: his filching was like an unskilful
Singer, he kept not time.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: The good humour is to steal at a minutes rest.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p:
Convey: the wise it call: Steal? foh: a fico for
the phrase.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Well sirs, I am almost out at heels.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p: Why then let Kibes ensue.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: There is no remedy: I must conycatch, I must shift.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p: Young Ravens must have food.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Which of you know Ford of this Town?

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p: I ken the wight: he is of substance good.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: My honest Lads, I will tell you what I am about.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p: Two yards, and more.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
No quips now Pistoll: (Indeed I am in the waste
two yards about: but I am now about no waste: I am about
thrift) briefly: I do mean to make love to Fords
wife: I spy entertainment in her: she discourses: she
carves: she gives the leer of invitation: I can construe
the action of her familiar style, and the hardest voice of her
behaviour (to be englished rightly) is, I am Sir Iohn Falstafs.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p:
He hath studied her will; and translated her will:
out of honesty, into English.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: The Anchor is deep: will that humour pass?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Now the report goes, she has all the rule of her
husbands Purse: he hath a legend of Angels.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p: As many devils entertain: and to her Boy say I.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: The humour rises: it is good: humour me the angels.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
I have writ me here a letter to her: and here another
to Pages wife, who even now gave me good eyes
too; examined my parts with most judicious illiads: sometimes
the beam of her view, gilded my foot: sometimes
my portly belly.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p: Then did the Sun on dung-hill shine.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: I thank thee for that humour.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
O she did so course over my exteriors with such
a greedy intention, that the appetite of her eye, did seem
to scorch me up like a burning glass: here is another
letter to her: She bears the Purse too: She is a Region
in Guiana: all gold, and bounty: I will be Cheaters to
them both, and they shall be Exchequers to me: they
shall be my East and West Indies, and I will trade to
them both: Go, bear thou this Letter to Mistress Page;
and thou this to Mistress Ford: we will thrive (Lads) we
will thrive.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: Shall I Sir Pandarus of Troy become,
And by my side wear Steel? then Lucifer take all.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p:
I will run no base humour: here take the humour-Letter;
I will keep the behaviour of reputation.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Hold Sirra, bear you these Letters tightly,
Sail like my Pinnace to these golden shores.
Rogues, hence avaunt, vanish like hailstones; go,
Trudge; plod away in the hoof: seek shelter, pack:
Falstaffe will learn the honour of the age,
French-thrift, you Rogues, myself, and skirted Page.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p:
Let Vultures gripe thy guts: for gourd, and
Fullam holds: and high and low beguiles the rich and poor,
Tester I will have in pouch when thou shalt lack,
Base Phrygian Turk.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.l: I have operations,
Which be humours of revenge.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: Wilt thou revenge?

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.l: By Welkin, and her Star.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: With wit, or Steel?

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.l: With both the humours, I:
I will discuss the humour of this Love to Ford.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: And I to Page shall eke unfold
How Falstaffe (varlet vile)
His Dove will prove; his gold will hold,
And his soft couch defile.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p:
My humour shall not cool: I will incense Ford
to deal with poison: I will possess him with yellowness,
for the revolt of mine is dangerous: that is my
true humour.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p:
Thou art the Mars of Malcontents: I second
thee: troop on.

div2.stage:
Enter Mistris Quickly, Simple, Iohn Rugby, Doctor,
Caius, Fenton.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p:
What, Iohn Rugby, I pray thee go to the Casement,
and see if you can see my Master, Master Doctor
Caius coming: if he do (I'faith) and find anybody
in the house; here will be an old abusing of Gods patience,
and the Kings English.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.p: I will go watch.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p:
Go, and we will have a posset for it soon at night,
(i'faith) at the latter end of a Sea-cole-fire: An honest,
willing, kind fellow, as ever servant shall come in house
withal: and I warrant you, no telltale, nor no breede-bate:
his worst fault is, that he is given to prayer; he is
something peevish that way: but nobody but has his
fault: but let that pass. Peter Simple, you say your
name is?

sp.speaker: Si..
sp.p: Aye: for fault of a better.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: And Master Slender is your Master?

sp.speaker: Si..
sp.p: Aye forsooth.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p:
Does he not wear a great round Beard, like a
Glovers pairing-knife?

sp.speaker: Si..
sp.p:
No forsooth: he hath but a little wee-face; with
a little yellow Beard: a Caine coloured Beard.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: A softly-sprighted man, is he not?

sp.speaker: Si..
sp.p:
Aye forsooth: but he is as tall a man of his hands, as
any is between this and his head: he hath fought with
a Warrener.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p:
How say you: o, I should remember him: does
he not hold up his head (as it were?) and strut in his gate?

sp.speaker: Si..
sp.p: Yes indeed does he.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p:
Well, heaven send Anne Page, no worse fortune:
Tell Master Parson Euans, I will do what I can for your
Master: Anne is a good girl, and I wish --

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.p: Out alas: here comes my Master.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p:
We shall all be shent: Run in here, good young
man: go into this Closet: he will not stay long: what
Iohn Rugby? Iohn: what Iohn I say? go Iohn, go enquire
for my Master, I doubt he be not well, that he
comes not home: (and down, down, adown etc.

sp.speaker: Ca.
Qu.
sp.p:
Aye forsooth I will fetch it you:
I am glad he went not in himself: if he had found the
young man he would have been horn mad.

p.foreign:
Fe, fe, fe, fe, mai foy, il faith for chando, Ie man voi a le
Court la grand affaires.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: Is it this Sir?

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p:
Ony mette le au mon pocket, de-peech quickly:
Where is that knave Rugby?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: What Iohn Rugby, Iohn?

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.p: Here Sir.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p:
You are Iohn Rugby, and you are Iacke Rugby:
Come, take your Rapier, and come after my heel to
the Court.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.p: It is ready Sir, here in the Porch.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p:
By my trot: I tarry too long: od's-me: que ay ie
oublie: there is some Simples in my Closet, that I will not
for the world I shall leave behind.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: Ay-me, he will find the young man there, and be mad.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p:
O Diable, Diable: what is in my Closet?
Villainy, La-roone: Rugby, my Rapier.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: Good Master be content.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Wherefore shall I be content?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: The young man is an honest man.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p:
What shall the honest man do in my Closet: there
is no honest man that shall come in my Closet.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p:
I beseech you be not so phlegmatic: hear the
truth of it. He came of an errand to me, from Parson
Hugh.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Si..
sp.p: Aye forsooth: to desire her to --

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: Peace, I pray you.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Peace your tongue: speak your Tale.

sp.speaker: Si..
sp.p:
To desire this honest Gentlewoman (your Maid)
to speak a good word to Mistress Anne Page, for my Master
in the way of Marriage.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p:
This is all indeed: but I will never put my finger
in the fire, and need not.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p:
Sir Hugh send you? Rugby, ballow me some
paper: tarry you a littell-a-while.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
I am glad he is so quiet: if he had been thoroughly
moved, you should have heard him so loud, and so melancholy;
but notwithstanding man, I will do you your
Master what good I can: and the very yea, and the no is, the
French Doctor my Master, (I may call him my Master,
look you, for I keep his house; and I wash, ring, brew,
bake, scour, dress meat and drink, make the beds, and
do all myself.)

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p:
It is a great charge to come under one bodies
hand.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
Are you advised of that? you shall find it a great
charge: and to be up early, and down late: but notwithstanding,
(to tell you in your ear, I would have no words
of it) my Master himself is in love with Mistress Anne
Page: but notwithstanding that I know Ans mind, that is
neither here nor there.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p:
You, Iack 'Nape: give this Letter to Sir
Hugh, by-gar it is a challenge: I will cut his throat in the
Parke, and I will teach a scurvy Iack-a-nape Priest to
meddle, or make: -- you may be gone: it is not good
you tarry here: by-gar I will cut all his two stones: by-gar,
he shall not have a stone to throw at his dog.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Alas: he speaks but for his friend.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p:
It is no matter for that: do not you tell me
that I shall have Anne Page for myself? by-gar, I will
kill the Iack-Priest: and I have appointed mine Host of
the Iarteer to measure our weapon: by-gar, I will myself
have Anne Page.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
Sir, the maid loves you, and all shall be well:
We must give folks leave to prate: what the good-ier.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p:
Rugby, come to the Court with me: by-gar, if
I have not Anne Page, I shall turn your head out of my
door: follow my heels, Rugby.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
You shall have A fool's head of your own:
No, I know Ans mind for that: never a woman in Windsor
knows more of Ans mind than I do, nor can do
more than I do with her, I thank heaven.

sp.speaker: Fenton.
sp.p: Who is within; there, ho?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
Who is there, I trow? Come near the house I
pray you.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.p: How now (good woman) how dost thou?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
The better that it pleases your good Worship
to ask?

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.p: What news? how does pretty Mistress Anne?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
In truth Sir, and she is pretty, and honest, and
gentle, and one that is your friend, I can tell you that by
the way, I praise heaven for it.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.p:
Shall I do any good thinkst thou? shall I not
loose my suit?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
Troth Sir, all is in his hands above: but notwithstanding
(Master Fenton) I will be sworn on a book
she loves you: have not your Worship a wart above
your eye?

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.p: Yes marry have I, what of that?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
Well, thereby hangs a tale: good faith, it is such
another Nan; (but (I detest) an honest maid as ever
broke bread: we had an hours talk of that wart; I
shall never laugh but in that maids company: but (indeed)
she is given too much to melanicholy and musing:
but for you -- well -- go to --

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.p:
Well: I shall see her today: hold, there is money
for thee: Let me have thy voice in my behalf: if
thou seest her before me, commend me. -- .

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
Will I? I'faith that we will: And I will tell
your Worship more of the Wart, the next time we have
confidence, and of other wooers.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.p: Well, fare-well, I am in great haste now.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
Fare-well to your Worship: truly an honest
Gentleman: but Anne loves him not: for I know Ans
mind as well as another does: out upon it: what have I
forgot.

div2.stage:
Enter Mistris Page, Mistris Ford, Master Page, Master
Ford, Pistoll, Nim, Quickly, Host, Shallow.

sp.speaker: Mist. Page.
sp.p:
What, have scaped Love-letters in the
holly-day-time of my beauty, and am I now a subject
for them? let me see?

Ask me no reason why I love you, for though Love use Reason
for his precisian, he admits him not for his Counsellor:
you are not young, no more am I: go to then, there is sympathy:
you are merry, so am I: ha, ha, then there is more sympathy:
you love sack, and so do I: would you desire better sympathy?
Let it suffice thee (Mistress Page) at the least if the Love of
Soldier can suffice, that I love thee: I will not say pity me,
it is not a Soldier-like phrase; but I say, love me:
sp.l: By me, thine own true Knight, by day or night:
Or any kind of light, with all his might,
For thee to fight. Iohn Falstaffe.

sp.p:
What a Herod of Jury is this? O wicked, wicked world:
One that is well-nigh worn to pieces with age
To show himself a young Gallant? What an unweighed
Behaviour hath this Flemish drunkard picked (with
The Devils name) out of my conversation, that he dares
In this manner assay me? why, he hath not been thrice
In my Company: what should I say to him? I was then
Frugal of my mirth: (heaven forgive me:) why I will
Exhibit a Bill in the Parliament for the putting down
of men: how shall I be revenged on him? for revenged I
will be? as sure as his guts are made of puddings.

sp.speaker: Mis Ford.
sp.p:
Mistress Page, trust me, I was going to your
house.

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p:
And trust me, I was coming to you: you
look very ill.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ford.
sp.p:
Nay, I will never believe that; I have to show
to the contrary.

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p: I'Faith but you do in my mind.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ford.
sp.p:
Well: I do then: yet I say, I could show
you to the contrary: O Mistress Page, give me some
counsel.

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p: What is the matter, woman?

sp.speaker: Mi. Ford.
sp.p:
O woman: if it were not for one trifling respect,
I could come to such honour.

sp.speaker: Mi. Page.
sp.p:
Hang the trifle (woman) take the honour:
what is it? dispense with trifles: what is it?

sp.speaker: Mi. Ford.
sp.p:
If I would but go to hell, for an eternal
moment, or so: I could be knighted.

sp.speaker: Mi. Page.
sp.p:
What thou liest? Sir Alice Ford? these
Knights will hack, and so thou shouldest not alter the article
of thy Gentry.

sp.speaker: Mi. Ford.
sp.p:
We burn day-light: here, read, read:
perceive how I might be knighted, I shall think the
worse of fat men, as long as I have an eye to make difference
of men's liking: and yet he would not swear:
praise women's modesty: and gave such orderly and well-behaved
reproof to all uncomeliness, that I would have
sworn his disposition would have gone to the truth of
his words: but they do no more adhere and keep place
together, than the hundred Psalms to the tune of Green-sleeves:
What tempest (I trow) threw this Whale, (with
so many Tuns of oil in his belly) ashore at Windsor?
How shall I be revenged on him? I think the best way
were, to entertain him with hope, till the wicked fire
of lust have melted him in his own grease: Did you ever
hear the like?

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p:
Letter for letter; but that the name of
Page and Ford differs: to thy great comfort in this mystery
of ill opinions, here is the twin-brother of thy Letter:
but let thine inherit first, for I protest mine never
shall: I warrant he hath a thousand of these Letters, writ
with blank space for different names (sure more): and
these are of the second edition: he will print them out
of doubt: for he cares not what he puts into the press,
when he would put us two: I had rather be a Giantess,
and lie under Mount Pelion: Well; I will find you twenty
lascivious Turtles ere one chaste man.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ford.
sp.p:
Why this is the very same: the very hand:
the very words: what doth he think of us?

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p:
Nay I know not: it makes me almost ready
to wrangle with mine own honesty: I will entertain
myself like one that I am not acquainted withal: for
sure unless he know some strain in me, that I know
not myself, he would never have boarded me in this
fury.

sp.speaker: Mi. Ford.
sp.p:
Boarding, call you it? I will be sure to keep
him above deck.

sp.speaker: Mi. Page.
sp.p:
So will I: if he come under my hatches,
I will never to Sea again: Let us be revenged on him: let us
appoint him a meeting: give him a show of comfort in
his Suit, and lead him on with a fine baited delay, till he
hath pawned his horses to mine Host of the Garter.

sp.speaker: Mi. Ford.
sp.p:
Nay, I will consent to act any villainy against
him, that may not sully the chariness of our honesty: o
that my husband saw this Letter: it would give eternal
food to his jealousy.

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p:
Why look where he comes; and my good
man too: he is as far from jealousy, as I am from giving
him cause, and that (I hope) is an unmeasurable distance.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ford.
sp.p: You are the happier woman.

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p:
Let us consult together against this greasy
Knight: Come hither.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Well: I hope, it be not so.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: Hope is a curtall-dog in some affairs:
Sir Iohn affects thy wife.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Why sir, my wife is not young.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p:
He woos both high and low, both rich and poor,
both young and old, one with another (Ford) he loves the
Gally-mawfry (Ford) perfumed.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Love my wife?

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: With liver, burning hot: prevent:
Or go thou like Sir Acteon he, with
Ring-wood at thy heels: O, odious is the name.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: What name Sir?

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: The horn I say: Farewell:
Take heed, have open eye, for thieves do foot by night.
Take heed, ere summer comes, or Cuckoo-birds do sing.
Away sir Corporal Nim:
Believe it (Page) he speaks sense.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: I will be patient: I will find out this.

sp.speaker: Nim.
sp.p:
And this is true: I like not the humour of lying:
he hath wronged me in some humours: I should have
borne the humoured Letter to her: but I have a sword:
and it shall bite upon my necessity: he loves your wife;
there is the short and the long: My name is Corporal
Nim: I speak, and I avouch; it is true: my name is Nim:
and Falstaffe loves your wife: adieu, I love not the humour
of bread and cheese: adieu.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
The humour of it (quoth he?) here is a fellow
frights English out of his wits.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: I will seek out Falstaffe.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: I never heard such a drawling-affecting rogue.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: If I do find it: well.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
I will not believe such a Cataian, though the
Priest of the Town commended him for a true man.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: It was a good sensible fellow: well.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: How now Meg?

sp.speaker: Mist. Page.
sp.p: Whether go you (George?) hark you.

sp.speaker: Mis Ford.
sp.p: How now (sweet Frank) why art thou melancholy?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: I melancholy? I am not melancholy:
Get you home: go.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ford.
sp.l: Faith, thou hast some crochets in thy head,
Now: will you go, Mistress Page?

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p:
Have with you: you will come to dinner
George? look who comes yonder: she shall be our
Messenger to this paltry Knight.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ford.
sp.p: Trust me, I thought on her: she will fit it.

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p: You are come to see my daughter Anne?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
Aye forsooth: and I pray how does good Mistress
Anne?

sp.speaker: Mis Page.
sp.p:
Go in with us and see: we have an hours
talk with you.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: How now Master Ford?

sp.speaker: For..
sp.p: You heard what this knave told me, did you not?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Yes, and you heard what the other told me?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Do you think there is truth in them?

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.p:
Hang them slaves: I do not think the Knight
would offer it: But these that accuse him in his intent
towards our wives, are a yoke of his discarded men: very
rogues, now they be out of service.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Were they his men?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Marry were they.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: I like it never the better for that,
Does he lie at the Garter?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Aye marry does he: if he should intend this voyage
toward my wife, I would turn her loose to him;
and what he gets more of her, than sharpe words, let it
lie on my head.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
I do not misdoubt my wife: but I would be
loath to turn them together: a man may be too confident:
I would have nothing lie on my head: I cannot
be thus satisfied.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
look where my ranting-Host of the Garter
comes: there is either liquor in his pate, or money in his
purse, when he looks so merrily: How now mine
Host?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
How now Bully-Rooke: thou art a Gentleman
Cavalier Justice, I say.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
I follow, (mine Host) I follow: Good-even,
and twenty (good Master Page.) Master Page, will you go
with us? we have sport in hand.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Tell him Caueleiro-Iustice: tell him Bully-Rooke.

sp.speaker: Shall.
sp.p:
Sir, there is a fray to be fought, between Sir
Hugh the Welsh Priest, and Caius the French Doctor.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Good mine Host of the Garter: a word with you.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: What sayst thou, my Bully-Rooke?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
Will you go with us to behold it? My merry
Host hath had the measuring of their weapons; and (I
think) hath appointed them contrary places: for (believe
me) I hear the Parson is no Jester: hark, I will
tell you what our sport shall be.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Hast thou no suit against my Knight? my guest-Caualeire?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
None, I protest: but I will give you a pottle of
burned sack, to give me recourse to him, and tell him
my name is Broome: only for a jest.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
My hand, (Bully:) thou shalt have egress and
regress, (said I well?) and thy name shall be Broome. It
is a merry Knight: will you go An-heiress?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Have with you mine Host.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
I have heard the French-man hath good skill
in his Rapier.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
Tut sir: I could have told you more: In these
times you stand on distance: your Passes, Stoccados, and
I know not what: it is the heart (Master Page) it is here,
it is here: I have seen the time with my long-sword, I
would have made you four tall fellows skip like
Rats.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Here boys, here, here: shall we wag?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Have with you: I had rather hear them scold,
than fight.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
Though Page be a secure fool, and stands so
firmly on his wives frailty; yet, I cannot put-off my opinion
so easily: she was in his company at Pages house:
and what they made there, I know not. Well, I will look
further into it, and I have a disguise, to sound Falstaffe; if
I find her honest, I loose not my labour: if she be otherwise,
it is labour well bestowed.

div2.stage: Enter Falstaffe, Pistoll, Robin, Quickly, Bardolffe, Ford.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I will not lend thee a penny.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p:
Why then the world is mine Oyster, which I,
with sword will open.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Not a penny: I have been content (Sir,) you
should lay my countenance to pawn: I have grated upon
my good friends for three Reprieves for you, and
your Coach-fellow Nim; or else you had looked through
the grate, like a Geminy of Baboons: I am damned in
hell, for swearing to Gentlemen my friends, you were
good Soldiers, and tall-fellows. And when Mistress
Briget lost the handle of her Fan, I took it upon mine honour
thou hadst it not.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p:
Didst not thou share? hadst thou not fifteen
pence?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Reason, you rogue, reason: thinkst thou I will endanger
my soul, gratis? at a word, hang no more about
me, I am no gibbet for you: go, a short knife, and a
throng, to your Manor of Pickt-hatch: go, you will not
bear a Letter for me you rogue? you stand upon your
honour: why, (thou unconfinable baseness) it is as much
as I can do to keep the terms of my honour precise:
I, I, I myself sometimes; leaving the fear of heaven on
the left hand, and hiding mine honour in my necessity, am
fain to shuffle: to hedge, and to lurch, and yet, you
Rogue, will en-sconce your rags; your Cat-a-Mountaine-lookes,
your red-lattice phrases, and your bold-beating-oaths,
under the shelter of your honour? you
will not do it? you?

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p: I do relent: what would thou more of man?

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Sir, here is a woman would speak with you.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Let her approach.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Give your worship good morrow.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Good-morrow, good-wife.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Not so if it please your worship.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Good maid then.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: I will be sworn,
As my mother was the first hour I was born.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I do believe the swearer; what with me?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
Shall I vouch-safe your worship a word, or
two?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Two thousand (fair woman) and I will vouchsafe
thee the hearing.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
There is one Mistress Ford, (Sir) I pray come a
little nearer this ways: I myself dwell with Master Doctor
Caius:

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Well, on; Mistress Ford, you say.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
Your worship says very true: I pray your worship
come a little near this ways.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
I warrant thee, nobody hears: mine own
people, mine own people.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
Are they so? heaven-bless them, and make
them his Servants.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Well; Mistress Ford, what of her?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
Why, Sir; she is a good-creature; Lord, Lord,
your Worship is a wanton: well: heaven forgive you,
and all of us, I pray --.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Mistress Ford: come, Mistress Ford.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
Marry this is the short, and the long of it: you
have brought her into such a Canaries, as it is wonderful:
he best Courtier of them all (when the Court lay
at Windsor) could never have brought her to such a Canary:
yet there has been Knights, and Lords, and Gentlemen,
with their Coaches; I warrant you Coach after
Coach, letter after letter, gift after gift, smelling so sweetly;
all Musk, and so rushling, I warrant you, in silk
and gold, and in such elegant terms, and in such wine
and sugar of the best, and the fairest, that would have
won any woman's heart: and I warrant you, they could
never get an eye-wink of her: I had myself twenty
Angels given me this morning, but I defy all Angels (in
any such sort, as they say) but in the way of honesty: and
I warrant you, they could never get her so much as sip
on a cup with the proudest of them all, and yet there has
been Earls: nay, (which is more) Pensioners, but I
warrant you all is one with her.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
But what says she to me? be brief my good
shee-Mercurie.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
Marry, she hath received your Letter: for the
which she thanks you a thousand times; and she gives
you to notify, that her husband will be absence from his
house, between ten and eleven.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Ten, and eleven.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
Aye, forsooth: and then you may come and see the
picture (she says) that you wot of: Master Ford her husband
will be from home: alas, the sweet woman leads
an ill life with him: he is a very iealousie-man; she leads
a very frampold life with him, (good heart.)

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Ten, and eleven.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
Why, you say well: But I have another messenger
to you/worship: Mistress Page hath her hearty
commendations to you too: and let me tell you in your
ear, she is as fartuous a civil modest wife, and one (I
tell you) that will not miss you morning nor evening
prayer, as any is in Windsor, whoever be the other: and
she bade me tell your worship, that her husband is seldom
from home, but she hopes there will come a time.
I never knew a woman so dote upon a man; surely I
think you have charms, la: yes in truth.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Not I, I assure thee; setting the attraction of my
good parts aside, I have no other charms.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Blessing on your heart for it.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
But I pray thee tell me this: has Fords wife, and
Pages wife acquainted each other, how they love me?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
That were a jest indeed: they have not so little
grace I hope, that were a trick indeed: But Mistress Page
would desire you to send her your little Page of all loves:
her husband has a marvelous infectio to the little Page:
and truly Master Page is an honest man: never a wife in
Windsor leads a better life than she does: do what she
will, say what she will, take all, pay all, go to bed when
she list, rise when she list, all is as she will: and truly she
deserves it; for if there be a kind woman in Windsor, she
is one: you must send her your Page, no remedy.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Why, I will.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p:
Nay, but do so then, and look you, he may
come and go between you both: and in any case have
a nay-word, that you may know one another's mind,
and the Boy never need to understand anything; for
it is not good that children should know any wickedness:
old folks you know, have discretion, as they say, and
know the world.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Farethee-well, commend me to them both:
there is my purse, I am yet thy debtor: Boy, go along
with this woman, this news distracts me.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: This Punk is one of Cupids Carriers,
Clap on more sails, pursue: up with your fights:
Give fire: she is my prize, or Ocean whelm them all.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Sayst thou so (old Iacke) go thy ways: I will make
more of thy old body than I have done: will they yet
look after thee? wilt thou after the expense of so much
money, be now a gainer? good Body, I thank thee: let
them say it is grossly done, so it be fairly done, no
matter.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p:
Sir Iohn, there is one Master Broome below would
fain speak with you, and be acquainted with you; and
hath sent your worship a mornings draught of Sack.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Broome is his name?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Aye Sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Call him in: such Broomes are welcome to me,
that overflows such liquor: ah ha, Mistress Ford and Mistress
Page, have I encompassed you? go to, via.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Bless you sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: And you sir: would you speak with me?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
I make bold, to press, with so little preparation
upon you.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
You are welcome, what is your will? give us leave
Drawer.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
Sir, I am a Gentleman that have spent much,
my name is Broome.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Good Master Broome, I desire more acquaintance
of you.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
Good Sir Iohn, I sue for yours: not to charge
you, for I must let you understand, I think myself in
better plight for a Lender, than you are: the which hath
something emboldened me to this unseasoned intrusion:
for they say, if money go before, all ways do lie
open.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Money is a good Soldier (Sir) and will on.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
Troth, and I have a bag of money here troubles
me: if you will help to bear it (Sir Iohn) take all,
or half, for easing me of the carriage.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Sir, I know not how I may deserve to be your
Porter.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: I will tell you sir, if you will give me the hearing.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Speak (good Master Broome) I shall be glad to
be your Servant.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
Sir, I hear you are a Scholar: (I will be brief
with you) and you have been a man long known to me,
though I had never so good means as desire, to make myself acquainted with you. I shall discover a thing to
you, wherein I must very much lay open mine own imperfection:
but (good Sir Iohn) as you have one eye upon
my follies, as you hear them unfolded, turn another
into the Register of your own, that I may pass with a
reproof the easier, sith you yourself know how easy it
is to be such an offender.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Very well Sir, proceed.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
There is a Gentlewoman in this Town, her
husbands name is Ford.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Well Sir.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
I have long loved her, and I protest to you, bestowed
much on her: followed her with a doting observance:
Engrossed opportunities to meet her: feed every
'slight occasion that could but niggardly give me
sight of her: not only bought many presents to give her,
but have given largely to many, to know what she
would have given: briefly, I have pursued her, as Love
hath pursued me, which hath been on the wing of all
occasions: but whatsoever I have merited, either in my
mind, or in my means, meed I am sure I have received
none, unless Experience be a Jewel, that I have purchased
at an infinite rate, and that hath taught me to say
this,
sp.l: Love like a shadow flies, when substance Love pursues,
"Pursuing that that flies, and flying what pursues.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Have you received no promise of satisfaction at
her hands?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Have you importuned her to such a purpose?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Of what quality was your love then?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
Like a fair house, built on another man's ground,
so that I have lost my edifice, by mistaking the place,
where I erected it.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: To what purpose have you unfolded this to me?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p:
When I have told you that, I have told you all:
Some say, that though she appear honest to me, yet in
other places she enlargeth her mirth so far, that there
is shrewd construction made of her. Now (Sir Iohn) here
is the heart of my purpose: you are a gentleman of excellent
breeding, admirable discourse, of great admittance,
authentic in your place and person, generally
allowed for your many war-like, court-like, and learned
preparations.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: O Sir.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
Believe it, for you know it: there is money,
spend it, spend it, spend more; spend all I have, only
give me so much of your time in enchange of it, as to lay
an amiable siege to the honesty of this Fords wife: use
your Art of wooing; win her to consent to you: if any
man may, you may as soon as any.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Would it apply well to the vehemency of your
affection that I should win what you would enjoy? Methinks
you prescribe to yourself very preposterously.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
O, understand my drift: she dwells so securely
on the excellency of her honour, that the folly of my soul
dares not present itself: she is too bright to be looked
against. Now, could I come to her with any detection
in my hand; my desires had instance and argument to
commend themselves, I could drive her then from the
ward of her purity, her reputation, her marriage-vow,
and a thousand other her defences, which now are too-too
strongly embattled against me: what say you to it,
Sir Iohn?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Master Broome, I will first make bold with your
money: next, give me your hand: and last, as I am a
gentleman, you shall, if you will, enjoy Fords wife.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: O good Sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I say you shall.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Want no money (Sir Iohn) you shall want none.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Want no Mistress Ford (Master Broome) you shall
want none: I shall be with her (I may tell you) by her
own appointment, even as you came in to me, her assistant,
or go-between, parted from me: I say I shall be
with her between ten and eleven: for at that time the
iealious-rascally-knaue her husband will be forth: come
you to me at night, you shall know how I speed.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
I am blessed in your acquaintance: do you know
Ford Sir?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Hang him (poor Cuckoldly knave) I know
him not: yet I wrong him to call him poor: They say
the jealous wittolly-knave hath masses of money, for
the which his wife seems to me well-favoured: I will use
her as the key of the Cuckoldly-rogues Coffer, and there is
my harvest-home.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
I would you knew Ford, sir, that you might avoid
him, if you saw him.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Hang him, mechanical-salt-butter rogue; I will
stare him out of his wits: I will awe him with my cudgel:
it shall hang like a Meteor over the Cuckolds horns:
Master Broome, thou shalt know, I will predominate over
the peasant, and thou shalt lie with his wife. Come
to me soon at night: Ford is a knave, and I will aggravate
his style: thou (Master Broome) shalt know him for
knave, and Cuckold. Come to me soon at night.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
What a damned epicurean-rascal is this? my
heart is ready to crack with impatience: who says this
is improvident jealousy? my wife hath sent to him, the
hour is fixed, the match is made: would any man have
thought this? see the hell of having a false woman: my
bed shall be abused, my Coffers ransacked, my reputation
gnawn at, and I shall not only receive this villainous
wrong, but stand under the adoption of abominable
terms, and by him that does me this wrong: Terms,
names: Amaimon sounds well: Lucifer, well: Barbason,
well: yet they are Devils additions, the names of fiends:
But Cuckold, Wittol, Cuckold? the Devil himself
hath not such a name. Page is an Ass, a secure Ass; he
will trust his wife, he will not be jealous: I will rather
trust a Fleming with my butter, Parson Hugh the Welsh-man
with my Cheese, an Irish-man with my Aqua-vitae-bottle,
or a Thief to walk my ambling gelding, than
my wife with herself. Then she plots, then she ruminates,
then she devises: and what they think in their
hearts they may effect; they will break their hearts but
they will effect. Heaven be praised for my jealousy:
eleven o'clock the hour, I will prevent this, detect
my wife, be revenged on Falstaffe, and laugh at Page. I
will about it, better three hours too soon, than a minute
too late: fie, fie, fie: Cuckold, Cuckold, Cuckold.

div2.stage: Enter Caius, Rugby, Page, Shallow, Slender, Host.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p: Iacke Rugby.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p: What is the clock, Iack.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.p:
It is past the hour (Sir) that Sir Hugh promised
to meet.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p:
By-gar, he has save his soul, that he is no-come:
he has pray his Bible well, that he is no-come: by-gar
(Iack Rugby) he is dead already, if he be come.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.p:
He is wise Sir: he knew your worship would
kill him if he came.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p:
By-gar, the herring is no dead, so as I will kill
him: take your Rapier, (Iacke) I will tell you how I will
kill him.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.p: Alas sir, I cannot fence.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: Villainy, take your Rapier.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.p: Forbear: here is company.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Bless thee, bully-Doctor.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Save you Mr. Doctor Caius.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Now good Mr. Doctor.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Give you good-morrow, sir.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p: What be all you one, two, tree, four, come for?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
To see thee fight, to see thee foin, to see thee
traverse, to see thee here, to see thee there, to see thee
pass thy puncto, thy stock, thy reverse, thy distance, thy
montant: Is he dead, my Ethiopian? Is he dead, my Francisco?
ha Bully? what says my Esculapius? my Galien? my
heart of Elder? ha? is he dead bully-Stale? is he dead?

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p:
By-gar, he is the Coward-Iack-Priest of the world:
he is not show his face.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Thou art a Castalion-king-Vrinall: Hector of
Greece (my Boy)

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p:
I pray you bear witness, that me have stay,
six or seven, two or tree hours for him, and he is no-come.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
He is the wiser man (Master Doctor) he is a curer of
souls, and you a curer of bodies: if you should fight, you
go against the hair of your professions: is it not true,
Master Page?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Master Shallow; you have yourself been a
great fighter, though now a man of peace.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
Body-kins Mister Page, though I now be old, and
of the peace; if I see a sword out, my finger itches to
make one: though we are Justices, and Doctors, and
Church-men (Mister Page) we have some salt of our youth
in us, we are the sons of women (Mister Page.)

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: It is true, Mr. Shallow.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
It will be found so, (Mister Page:) Master Doctor Caius,
I am come to fetch you home: I am sworn of the peace:
you have showed yourself a wise Physician, and Sir
Hugh hath shown himself a wise and patient Churchman:
you must go with me, Master Doctor.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Pardon, Guest-Iustice; a Monsieur Mocke-water.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: Mock-vater? what is that?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Mock-water, in our English tongue, is Valour
(Bully.)

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p:
By-gar, then I have as much Mock-vater as the
Englishman: scuruy-Iack-dog-Priest: by-gar, me will
cut his ears.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: He will Clapper-claw thee tightly (Bully.)

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: Clapper-de-claw? what is that?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: That is, he will make thee amends.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p:
By-gar, me do look he shall clapper-de-claw
me, for by-gar, me will have it.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: And I will provoke him to it, or let him wag.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: Me thank you for that.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
And moreover, (Bully) but first, Mr. Ghuest,
and Mister Page, and eke Cavalier Slender, go you through
the Town to Frogmore.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Sir Hugh is there, is he?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
He is there, see what humour he is in: and I will
bring the Doctor about by the Fields: will it do well?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: We will do it.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Adieu, good Master Doctor.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p:
By-gar, me will kill the Priest, for he speak for a
Iack-an-Ape to Anne Page.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Let him die: sheath thy impatience: throw cold
water on thy Choler: go about the fields with me
through Frogmore, I will bring thee where Mistress Anne
Page is, at a Farm-house a-Feasting: and thou shalt woo
her: Cride-game, said I well?

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p:
By-gar, me dank you for that: by-gar I love
you: and I shall procure you the good Guest: the Earl,
the Knight, the Lords, the Gentlemen, my patients.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
For the which, I will be thy adversary toward
Anne Page: said I well?

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: By-gar, it is good: well said.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Let us wag then.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: Come at my heels, Iack Rugby.

div2.stage:
Enter Euans, Simple, Page, Shallow, Slender, Host, Caius,
Rugby.

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p:
I pray you now, good Master Slanders serving-man,
and friend Simple by your name; which way have
you looked for Master Caius, that calls himself Doctor
of Physic.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p:
Marry Sir, the pittie-ward, the Parke-ward:
every way: old Windsor way, and every way but the
Towne-way.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p:
I most vehemently desire you, you will also
look that way.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I will sir.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p:
Bless my soul: how full of Cholers I am, and
trembling of mind: I shall be glad if he have deceived
me: how melancholy I am? I will knog his Urinals about
his knaves costard, when I have good opportunities
for the work: Bless my soul: To shallow Rivers to whose
falls: melodious Birds sings Madrigals: There will we make
our Beds of Roses: and a thousand fragrant posies. To shallow:
Mercy on me, I have a great dispositions to cry,
Melodious birds sing Madrigals:-- When as I sat in Pavilion:
and a thousand vagram Posies. To shallow, etc.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Yonder he is coming, this way, Sir Hugh.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p:
He is welcome: To shallow Rivers, to whose falls:
Heaven prosper the right: what weapons is he?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p:
No weapons, Sir: there comes my Master, Mr.
Shallow, and another Gentleman; from Frogmore, over
the style, this way.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p:
Pray you give me my gown, or else keep it
in your arms.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
How now Master Parson? good morrow good
Sir Hugh: keep a Gamester from the dice, and a good
Studient from his book, and it is wonderful.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Ah sweet Anne Page.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Save you, good Sir Hugh.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: Bless you from his mercy-sake, all of you.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: What? the Sword, and the Word?
Do you study them both, Mr. Parson?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
And youthful still, in your doublet and hose,
this raw-rumaticke day?

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: There is reasons, and causes for it.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
We are come to you, to do a good office, Mr.
Parson.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: Very well: what is it?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Yonder is a most reverend Gentleman; who
(be-like) having received wrong by some person, is at
most odds with his own gravity and patience, that ever
you saw.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
I have lived fourscore years, and upward: I
never heard a man of his place, gravity, and learning, so
wide of his own respect.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: What is he?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
I think you know him: Mr. Doctor Caius the
renowned French Physician.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p:
God's-will, and his passion of my heart: I had
as lief you would tell me of a mess of porridge.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p:
He has no more knowledge in Hibocrates and
Galen, and he is a knave besides: a cowardly knave, as
you would desires to be acquainted withal.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
I warrant you, he is the man should fight with
him.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: O sweet Anne Page.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
It appears so by his weapons: keep them asunder:
here comes Doctor Caius.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Nay good Mr. Parson, keep in your weapon.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: So do you, good Mr. Doctor.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Disarm them, and let them question: let them
keep their limbs whole, and hack our English.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p:
I pray you let me speak a word with your
ear; wherefore will you not meet me?

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: Pray you use your patience in good time.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p:
By-gar, you are the Coward: the Iack dog: Iohn
Ape.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p:
Pray you let us not be laughing-stocks to other
men's humours: I desire you in friendship, and I will one
way or other make you amends: I will knog your Urinal
about your knaves Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p:
Diable: Iack Rugby: mine Host the Iarteer: have I
not stay for him, to kill him? have I not at the place I did
appoint?

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p:
As I am a Christian-soul, now look you:
this is the place appointed, I will be judgment by mine
Host of the Garter.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Peace, I say, Gallia and Gaule, French and Welsh,
Soule-Curer, and Body-Curer.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: Aye, that is very good, excellent.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Peace, I say: hear mine Host of the Garter,
Am I politic? Am I subtle? Am I a Machiuell?
sp.p:
Shall I loose my Doctor? No, he gives me the Potions
and the Motions. Shall I loose my Parson? my Priest?
my Sir Hugh? No, he gives me the Proverbs, and the
No-verbs. Give me thy hand (Celestial) so: Boys of
Art, I have deceived you both: I have directed you to
wrong places: your hearts are mighty, your skins are
whole, and let burned Sack be the issue: Come, lay their
swords to pawn: Follow me, Lad of peace, follow, follow,
follow.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Trust me, a mad Host: follow Gentlemen, follow.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: O sweet Anne Page.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p:
Ha do I perceive that? Have you make the sot
of us, ha, ha?

sp.speaker: Eua.
sp.p:
This is well, he has made us his flouting-stock:
I desire you that we may be friends: and let us knog our
brains together to be revenge on this same scall scuruy-cogging-companion
the Host of the Garter.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p:
By-gar, with all my heart: he promise to bring
me where is Anne Page: by-gar he deceive me too.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: Well, I will smite his noddles: pray you follow.

div2.stage:
Mist. Page, Robin, Ford, Page, Shallow, Slender, Host,
Euans, Caius.

sp.speaker: Mist. Page.
sp.p:
Nay keep your way (little Gallant) you
were wont to be a follower, but now you are a Leader:
whether had you rather lead mine eyes, or eye your masters
heels?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p:
I had rather (forsooth) go before you like a man,
than follow him like a dwarf.

sp.speaker: M. Pa.
sp.p: O you are a flattering boy, now I see you will be a Courtier.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Well met Mistress Page, whether go you.

sp.speaker: M. Pa.
sp.p: Truly Sir, to see your wife, is she at home?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
Aye, and as idle as she may hang together for want
of company: I think if your husbands were dead, you
two would marry.

sp.speaker: M. Pa.
sp.p: Be sure of that, two other husbands.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Where had you this pretty weathercock?

sp.speaker: M. Pa.
sp.p:
I cannot tell what (the dickens) his name is my
husband had him of, what do you call your Knights name sirrah?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Sir Iohn Falstaffe.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Sir Iohn Falstaffe.

sp.speaker: M. Pa.
sp.p:
He, he, I can never hit on his name; there is such a
league between my goodman, and he: is your Wife at home indeed?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Indeed she is.

sp.speaker: M. Pa.
sp.p: By your leave sir, I am sick till I see her.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
Has Page any brains? Hath he any eyes? Hath he
any thinking? Sure they sleep, he hath no use of them:
why this boy will carry a letter twenty mile as easy, as
a Canon will shoot point-blank twelve score: he pieces
out his wives inclination: he gives her folly motion
and advantage: and now she is going to my wife, and Falstaffes
boy with her: A man may hear this shower sing
in the wind; and Falstaffes boy with her: good plots,
they are laid, and our revolted wives share damnation
together. Well, I will take him, then torture my wife,
pluck the borrowed vail of modesty from the so-seeming
Mistress Page, divulge Page himself for a secure and
wilful Acteon, and to these violent proceedings all my
neighbours shall cry aim. The clock gives me my Qu,
and my assurance bids me search, there I shall find Falstaffe:
I shall be rather praised for this, than mocked, for
it is as positive, as the earth is firm, that Falstaffe is
there: I will go.

sp.speaker: Shal. Page etc.
sp.p: Well met Mr Ford.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
Trust me, a good knot; I have good cheer at
home, and I pray you all go with me.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: I must excuse myself Mr Ford.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.l: And so must I Sir,
We have appointed to dine with Mistress Anne,
And I would not break with her for more money
Than I will speak of.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
We have lingered about a match between Anne
Page, and my cozen Slender, and this day we shall have
our answer.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: I hope I have your good will Father Page.

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.l: You have Mr Slender, I stand wholly for you,
But my wife (Mr Doctor) is for you altogether.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p:
Aye beggar, and the Maid is love me: my nursh-a-Quickly
tell me so mush.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
What say you to young Mr Fenton? He capers,
he dances, he has eyes of youth: he writes verses, he
speaks holiday, he smells April and May, he will carry it,
he will carry it, it is in his buttons, he will carry it.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Not by my consent I promise you. The Gentleman
is of no having, he kept company with the wild
Prince, and Pointz: he is of too high a Region, he knows
too much: no, he shall not knit a knot in his fortunes,
with the finger of my substance: if he take her, let him
take her simply: the wealth I have waits on my consent,
and my consent goes not that way.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
I beseech you heartily, some of you go home
with me to dinner: besides your cheer you shall have
sport, I will show you a monster: Mr Doctor, you shall
go, so shall you Mr Page, and you Sir Hugh.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: Well, fare you well:
We shall have the freer wooing at Mr Pages.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: Go home Iohn Rugby, I come anon.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Farewell my hearts, I will to my honest Knight
Falstaffe, and drink Canary with him.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
I think I shall drink in Pipe-wine first with
him, I will make him dance. Will you go, Gentles?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Have with you, to see this Monster.

div2.stage:
Enter M. Ford, M. Page, Seruants, Robin, Falstaffe,
Ford, Page, Caius, Euans.

sp.speaker: Mist. Ford.
sp.p: What Iohn, what Robert.

sp.speaker: M, Page.
sp.p: Quickly, quickly: Is the Buck-basket --

sp.speaker: Mis. Ford.
sp.p: I warrant. What Robin I say.

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p: Come, come, come.

sp.speaker: Mist. Ford.
sp.p: Here, set it down.

sp.speaker: M. Pag.
sp.p: Give your men the charge, we must be brief.

sp.speaker: M. Ford.
sp.p:
Marry, as I told you before (Iohn and Robert)
be ready here hard-by in the Brew-house, and when I suddenly
call you, come forth, and (without any pause, or
staggering) take this basket on your shoulders: that done,
trudge with it in all hast, and carry it among the Whitsters
in Dotchet Mead, and there empty it in the muddy
ditch, close by the Thames side.

sp.speaker: M. Page.
sp.p: You will do it?

sp.speaker: M. Ford.
sp.p: I have told them over and over, they lack no direction.
Be gone, and come when you are called.

sp.speaker: M. Page.
sp.p: Here comes little Robin.

sp.speaker: Mist. Ford.
sp.p: How now my Eyas-Musket, what news with you?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p:
My Master Sir Iohn is come in at your back door
(Mistress Ford, and requests your company.

sp.speaker: M. Page.
sp.p: You little Iack-a-lent, have you been true to us

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p:
Aye, I will be sworn: my Master knows not of your
being here: and hath threatened to put me into everlasting
liberty, if I tell you of it: for he swears he will turn
me away.

sp.speaker: Mist. Pag.
sp.p:
Thou art a good boy: this secrecy of thine
shall be a Tailor to thee, and shall make thee a new doublet
and hose. I will go hide me.

sp.speaker: Mi. Ford.
sp.p:
Do so: go tell thy Master, I am alone: Mistress
Page, remember you your Qu.

sp.speaker: Mist. Pag.
sp.p: I warrant thee, if I do not act it, hiss me.

sp.speaker: Mist. Ford.
sp.p:
Go to then: we will use this unwholesome
humidity, this grosse-watry Pumpion; we will teach him
to know Turtles from Jays.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Have I caught thee, my heavenly Jewel? Why
now let me die, for I have lived long enough: This is the
period of my ambition: O this blessed hour.

sp.speaker: Mist. Ford.
sp.p: O sweet Sir Iohn.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Mistress Ford, I cannot cog, I cannot prate (Mistress
Ford) now shall I sin in my wish; I would thy Husband
were dead, I will speak it before the best Lord, I would
make thee my Lady.

sp.speaker: Mist. Ford.
sp.p:
I your Lady Sir Iohn? Alas, I should be a
pitiful Lady.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Let the Court of France show me such another:
I see how thine eye would emulate the Diamond: Thou
hast the right arched-beauty of the brow, that becomes
the Ship-tyre, the Tyre-valiant, or any Tire of Venetian
admittance.

sp.speaker: Mist. Ford.
sp.l: A plain Kerchief, Sir Iohn:
My brows become nothing else, nor that well neither.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Thou art a tyrant to say so: thou wouldst make
an absolute Courtier, and the firm fixture of thy foot,
would give an excellent motion to thy gate, in a semi-circled
Farthingale. I see what thou wert if Fortune thy
foe, were not Nature thy friend: Come, thou canst not
hide it.

sp.speaker: Mist. Ford.
sp.p: Believe me, there is no such thing in me.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
What made me love thee? Let that persuade
thee. There is something extraordinary in thee: Come, I
cannot cog, and say thou art this and that, like many
of these lisping-hauthorne buds, that come like women
in men's apparel, and smell like Bucklers-berry in simple
time: I cannot, but I love thee, none but thee; and
thou deservest it.

sp.speaker: M. Ford.
sp.p: Do not betray me sir, I fear you love Mister Page.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Thou mightst as well say, I love to walk by the
Counter-gate, which is as hateful to me, as the reek of
a Lime-kill.

sp.speaker: Mis Ford.
sp.l: Well, heaven knows how I love you,
And you shall one day find it.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Keep in that mind, I will deserve it.

sp.speaker: Mist. Ford.
sp.l: Nay, I must tell you, so you do;
Or else I could not be in that mind.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p:
Mistress Ford, Mistress Ford: here is Mistress Page at
the door, sweating, and blowing, and looking wildly,
and would needs speak with you presently.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
She shall not see me, I will ensconce me behind
the Arras.

sp.speaker: M. Ford.
sp.p:
Pray you do so, she is a very tattling woman.
What is the matter? How now?

sp.speaker: Mist. Page.
sp.l: O Mistress Ford what have you done?
You are shamed, you are overthrown, you are undone forever.

sp.speaker: M. Ford.
sp.p: What is the matter, good Mistress Page?

sp.speaker: M. Page.
sp.p:
O weladay, mistress Ford, having an honest man
to your husband, to give him such cause of suspicion.

sp.speaker: M. Ford.
sp.p: What cause of suspicion?

sp.speaker: M. Page.
sp.l: What cause of suspicion? Out upon you:
How am I mistook in you?

sp.speaker: M. Ford.
sp.p: Why (alas) what is the matter?

sp.speaker: M. Page.
sp.p:
Your husband is coming hither (Woman)
with all the Officers in Windsor, to search for a Gentleman,
that he says is here now in the house; by your
consent to take an ill advantage of his absence: you are
undone.

sp.speaker: M. Ford.
sp.p: It is not so, I hope.

sp.speaker: M. Page.
sp.p:
Pray heaven it be not so, that you have such
a man here: but it is most certain your husband is coming,
with half Windsor at his heels, to search for such
a one, I come before to tell you: If you know yourself
clear, why I am glad of it: but if you have a friend here,
convey, convey him out. Be not amazed, call all your
senses to you, defend your reputation, or bid farewell to
your good life forever.

sp.speaker: M. Ford.
sp.p:
What shall I do? There is a Gentleman my
dear friend: and I fear not mine own shame so much,
as his peril. I had rather than a thousand pound he were
out of the house.

sp.speaker: M. Page.
sp.p:
For shame, never stand (you had rather, and
you had rather:) your husband is here at hand, bethink
you of some conveyance: in the house you cannot hide
him. O, how have you deceived me? Look, here is a
basket, if he be of any reasonable stature, he may creep
in here, and throw foul linen upon him, as if it were
going to bucking: Or it is whiting time, send him by
your two men to Datchet-Meade.

sp.speaker: M. Ford.
sp.p: He is too big to go in there: what shall I do?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Let me see it, let me see it, O let me see it:
I will in, I will in: Follow your friends counsel, I will in.

sp.speaker: M. Page.
sp.p:
What Sir Iohn Falstaffe? Are these your Letters,
Knight?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
I love thee, help me away: let me creep in
here: I will never --

sp.speaker: M. Page.
sp.p:
Help to cover your master (Boy:) Call
your men (Mistress Ford.) You dissembling Knight.

sp.speaker: M. Ford.
sp.p:
What Iohn, Robert, Iohn; Go, take up these
clothes here, quickly: Where is the Cowl-staff? Look
how you drumble? Carry them to the Laundress in Datchet
mead: quickly, come.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Pray you come near: if I suspect without cause,
Why then make sport at me, then let me be your jest,
I deserve it: How now? Whether bear you this?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: To the Laundress forsooth?

sp.speaker: M. Ford.
sp.p:
Why, what have you to do whether they
bear it? You were best meddle with buck-washing.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Buck? I would I could wash myself of the Buck:
Bucke, bucke, bucke, I bucke: I warrant you Bucke,
And of the season too; it shall appear.
sp.p:
Gentlemen, I have dreamed tonight, I will tell you my
dream: here, here, here be my keys, ascend my
Chambers, search, seek, find out: I will warrant we will
unkennel the Fox. Let me stop this way first: so, now
uncape.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Good master Ford, be contented:
You wrong yourself too much.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: True (master Page) up Gentlemen,
You shall see sport anon:
Follow me Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p: This is very fantastical humours and jealousies.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.l: By-gar, it is no the fashion of France:
It is not jealous in France.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Nay follow him (Gentlemen) see the issue of
his search.

sp.speaker: Mist. Page
sp.p: Is there not a double excellency in this?

sp.speaker: Mist. Ford.
sp.l: I know not which pleases me better,
That my husband is deceived, or Sir Iohn.

sp.speaker: Mist. Page.
sp.p:
What a taking was he in, when your
husband asked who was in the basket?

sp.speaker: Mist. Ford.
sp.p:
I am half afraid he will have need of
washing: so throwing him into the water, will do him
a benefit.

sp.speaker: Mist. Page.
sp.p:
Hang him dishonest rascal: I would all
of the same strain, were in the same distress.

sp.speaker: Mist. Ford.
sp.p:
I think my husband hath some special
suspicion of Falstaffs being here: for I never saw him so
gross in his jealousy till now.

sp.speaker: Mist. Page.
sp.p:
I will lay a plot to try that, and we will
yet have more tricks with Falstaffe: his dissolute disease
will scarce obey this medicine.

sp.speaker: Mis Ford
sp.p:
Shall we send that foolishion Carrion, Mistress
Quickly to him, and excuse his throwing into the water,
and give him another hope, to betray him to another
punishment?

sp.speaker: Mist. Page.
sp.p:
We will do it: let him be sent for tomorrow
eight o'clock to have amends.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
I cannot find him: may be the knave bragged
of that he could not compass.

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p: Heard you that?

sp.speaker: Mis. Ford.
sp.p: You use me well, Mister Ford? Do you?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Aye, I do so.

sp.speaker: M. Ford.
sp.p: Heaven make you better than your thoughts

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Amen

sp.speaker: Mi. Page.
sp.p: You do yourself mighty wrong (Mister Ford)

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Aye, aye: I must bear it.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p:
