If there be anybody in the house, and in the chambers,
and in the coffers, and in the presses: heaven forgive
my sins at the day of judgment.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p: By-gar, nor I too: there is no-bodies.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Fie, fie, Mister Ford, are you not ashamed? What spirit,
what devil suggests this imagination? I would not have
your distemper in this kind, for the wealth of Windsor castle.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: It is my fault (Mister Page) I suffer for it.

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p:
You suffer for a bad conscience: your wife is
as honest a o'mans, as I will desires among five thousand,
and five hundred too.

sp.speaker: Mis Ford
sp.p: By-gar, I see it is an honest woman.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
Well, I promised you a dinner: come, come, walk
in the Parke, I pray you pardon me. I will hereafter make
known to you why I have done this. Come wife, come
Mistress Page, I pray you pardon me. Pray heartily pardon me.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Let us go in Gentlemen, but (trust me) we will mock
him: I do invite you tomorrow morning to my house
to breakfast: after we will a-birding together, I have a fine
Hawk for the bush. Shall it be so:

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Anything.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: If there is one, I shall make two in the Company

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: If there be one, or two, I shall make the third.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Pray you go, Mister Page.

sp.speaker: Eua.
sp.p:
I pray you now remembrance tomorrow on the
lousy knave, mine Host.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: That is good by-gar, withal my heart.

sp.speaker: Eua.
sp.p: A lousy knave, to have his gibes, and his mockeries.

div2.stage:
Enter Fenton, Anne, Page, Shallow, Slender, Quickly, Page,Shallow, Slender,
Quickly, Page, Mist. Page.

sp.speaker: Fen:
sp.l: I see I cannot get thy Fathers love,
Therefore no more turn me to him (sweet Nan.)

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: Alas, how then?

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.l: Why thou must be thyself.
He doth object, I am too great of birth,
And that my state being galled with my expense,
I seek to heal it only by his wealth.
Besides these, other bars he lays before me,
My Riots past, my wild Societies,
And tells me it is a thing impossible
I should love thee, but as a property.

sp.speaker: An..
sp.l: May be he tells you true.
No, heaven so speed me in my time to come,
Albeit I will confess, thy Fathers wealth
Was the first motive that I wooed thee (Anne:)
Yet wooing thee, I found thee of more value
Than stamps in Gold, or sums in sealed bags:
And it is the very riches of thyself,
That now I aim at.

sp.speaker: An..
sp.l: Gentle Mister Fenton,
Yet seek my Fathers love, still seek it sir,
If opportunity and humblest suite
Cannot attain it, why then hark you hither.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: Break their talk Mistress Quickly,
My Kinsman shall speak for himself.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: I will make a shaft or a bolt of it, 'slid, it is but venturing.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Be not dismayed.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.l: No, she shall not dismay me:
I care not for that, but that I am afeared.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Hark ye, Mister Slender would speak a word with you

sp.speaker: An..
sp.l: I come to him. This is my Fathers choice:
O what a world of wild ill-favoured faults
Looks handsome in three hundred pounds a year?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: And how does good Master Fenton?
Pray you a word with you.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.l: She is coming; to her Cuz:
O boy, thou hadst a father.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
I had a father (Mistress Anne) my uncle can tell you good
jests of him: pray you Uncle tell Mistress Anne the jest how
my Father stole two Geese out of a Pen, good Uncle.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Mistress Anne, my Cozen loves you.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Aye that I do, as well as I love any woman in Glocestershire.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: He will maintain you like a Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
Aye that I will, come cut and long-tail, under the
degree of a Squire.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
He will make you a hundred and fifty pounds
jointure.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.p: Good Master Shallow let him woo for himself.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
Marry I thank you for it: I thank you for
that good comfort: she calls you (Cuz) I will leave you.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.p: Now Master Slender.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Now good Mistress Anne.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: What is your will?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
My will? Odd's-hart-lings, that is a pretty
jest indeed: I never made my Will yet (I thank Heaven:)
I am not such a sickly creature, I give Heaven
praise.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.l: I mean (Mister Slender) what would you with me?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
Truly, for mine own part, I would little or
nothing with you: your father and my uncle hath made
motions: if it be my luck, so; if not, happy man be his
dole, they can tell you how things go, better than I can:
you may ask your father, here he comes.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Now Mr Slender; Love him daughter Anne.
Why how now? What does Mr Fenten here?
You wrong me Sir, thus still to haunt my house:
I told you Sir, my daughter is disposed of.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.l: Nay Mr Page, be not impatient.

sp.speaker: Mist. Page.
sp.p: Good Mister Fenton. come not to my child.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: She is no match for you.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.l: Sir, will you hear me?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: No, good Mister Fenton.
Come Mister Shallow: Come son Slender, in;
Knowing my mind, you wrong me (Mister Fenton.)

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Speak to Mistress Page.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.l: Good Mistress Page, for that I love your daughter
In such a righteous fashion as I do,
Perforce, against all checks, rebukes, and manners,
I must advance the colours of my love,
And not retire. Let me have your good will.

sp.speaker: An..
sp.l: Good mother, do not marry me to yond fool.

sp.speaker: Mist. Page.
sp.p: I mean it not, I seek you a better husband.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: That is my master, Master Doctor.

sp.speaker: An..
sp.l: Alas I had rather be set quick in the earth,
And bowled to death with Turnips.

sp.speaker: Mist. Page.
sp.p:
Come, trouble not yourself good Mister
Fenton, I will not be your friend, nor enemy:
sp.l: My daughter will I question how she loves you,
And as I find her, so am I affected:
Till then, farewell Sir, she must needs go in,
Her father will be angry.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.l: Farewell gentle Mistress: farewell Nan.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
This is my doing now: Nay, said I, will you
cast away your child on a Fool, and a Physician:
sp.l: Look on Mister Fenton, this is my doing.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.l: I thank thee: and I pray thee once tonight,
Give my sweet Nan this Ring: there is for thy pains.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
Now heaven send thee good fortune, a kind
heart he hath: a woman would run through fire and water
for such a kind heart. But yet, I would my Master
had Mistress Anne, or I would Mister Slender had her: or (in
sooth) I would Mister Fenton had her; I will do what I can
for them all three, for so I have promised, and I will be as
good as my word, but speciously for Mister Fenton. Well, I
must of another errand to Sir Iohn Falstaffe from my two
Mistresses: what a beast am I to slack it.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Bardolfe I say.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Here Sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Go, fetch me a quart of Sack, put a tossed in it.
Have I lived to be carried in a Basket like a barrow of
butchers Offal? and to be thrown in the Thames? Well,
if I be served such another trick, I will have my brains
taken out and buttered, and give them to a dog for a
New-years gift. The rogues slighted me into the river
with as little remorse, as they would have drowned a
blind bitches Puppies, fifteen in the litter: and you may
know by my size, that I have a kind of alacrity in sinking:
if the bottom were as deep as hell, I should down.
I had been drowned, but that the shore was shelfy and
shallow: a death that I abhor: for the water swells a
man; and what a thing should I have been, when I
had been swelled? I should have been a Mountain of
Mummie.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Here is Mister Quickly Sir to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Come, let me pour in some Sack to the Thames
water: for my belly is as cold as if I had swallowed snow
balls, for pills to cool the reins. Call her in.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Come in woman.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: By your leave: I cry you mercy?
Give your worship good morrow.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Take away these Chalices:
Go, brew me a pottle of Sack finely.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.p: With Eggs, Sir?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Simple of itself: I will no Pullet-Spersme in my
brewage. How now?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Marry Sir, I come to your worship from Mister Ford.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Mistress Ford? I have had Ford enough: I was thrown
into the Ford; I have my belly full of Ford.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
Alas the day, (good-heart) that was not her
fault: she does so take on with her men; they mistook
their erection.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: So did I mine, to build upon a foolish Woman's promise.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
Well, she laments Sir for it, that it would yearn
your heart to see it: her husband goes this morning a-birding;
she desires you once more to come to her, between
eight and nine: I must carry her word quickly,
she will make you amends I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Well, I will visit her, tell her so: and bid her
think what a man is: Let her consider his frailty, and
then judge of my merit.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: I will tell her.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Do so. Between nine and ten sayst thou?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Eight and nine Sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Well, be gone: I will not miss her.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Peace be with you Sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
I marvel I hear not of Mr Broome: he sent me
word to stay within: I like his money well.
O, here he comes.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Bless you Sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Now Master Broome, you come to know
What hath past between me, and Fords wife.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: That indeed (Sir Iohn) is my business.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Master Broome I will not lie to you,
I was at her house the hour she appointed me.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: And sped you Sir?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: very ill-favouredly Master Broome.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: How so sir, did she change her determination?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
No (Master Broome) but the peaking Cornute her husband
(Master Broome) dwelling in a continual larum of jealousy,
comes me in the instant of our encounter, after we had
embraced, kissed, protested, and (as it were) spoke the prologue
of our Comedy: and at his heels, a rabble of his companions,
thither provoked and instigated by his distemper,
and (forsooth) to search his house for his wives Love.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: What? While you were there?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: While I was there.

sp.speaker: For..
sp.p: And did he search for you, and could not find you?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
You shall hear. As good luck would have it,
comes in one Mistress Page, gives intelligence of Fords approach:
and in her invention, and Fords wives distraction,
they conveyed me into a bucke-basket.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: A Buck-basket?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Yes: a Buck-basket: rammed me in with foul
Shirts and Smocks, Socks, foul Stockings, greasy
Napkins, that (Master Broome) there was the rankest
compound of villainous smell, that ever offended nostril.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: And how long lay you there?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Nay, you shall hear (Master Broome) what I
have suffered, to bring this woman to evil, for your
good: Being thus crammed in the Basket, a couple of
Fords knaves, his Hinds, were called forth by their Mistress,
to carry me in the name of foul Clothes to
Datchet-lane: they took me on their shoulders: met
the jealous knave their Master in the door; who
asked them once or twice what they had in their Basket?
I quaked for fear least the Lunatic Knave
would have searched it: but Fate (ordaining he should
be a Cuckold) held his hand: well, on went he, for
a search, and away went I for foul Clothes: But
mark the sequel (Master Broome) I suffered the pangs
of three several deaths: First, an intolerable fright,
to be detected with a jealous rotten Bell-weather:
Next to be compassed like a good Bilbo in the circumference
of a Peck, hilt to point, heel to head. And
then to be stopped in like a strong distillation with stinking
Clothes, that fretted in their own grease:
think of that, a man of my Kidney; think of that,
that am as subject to heat as butter; a man of continual
dissolution, and thaw: it was a miracle to scape
suffocation. And in the height of this Bath (when I
was more than half stewed in grease (like a Dutch-dish)
to be thrown into the Thames, and
cooled, glowing-hot, in that serge like a Horse-shoo;
think of that; hissing hot: think of that (Master Broome.)

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
In good sadness Sir, I am sorry, that for my sake
you have suffered all this.

My suite then is desperate: You will undertake her no
more?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Master Broome: I will be thrown into Etna,
as I have been into Thames, ere I will leave her thus;
her Husband is this morning gone a-birding: I
have received from her another embassy of meeting:
betwixt eight and nine is the hour (Master
Broome.)

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: It is past eight already Sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Is it? I will then address me to my appointment:
Come to me at your convenient leisure, and
you shall know how I speed: and the conclusion
shall be crowned with your enjoying her: adieu: you
shall have her (Master Broome) Master Broome, you shall
cuckold Ford.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
Hum: ha? Is this a vision? Is this a dream?
do I sleep? Master Ford awake, awake Master Ford:
there is a hole made in your best coat (Master Ford:) this
it is to be married; this it is to have Linen, and Buck-baskets:
Well, I will proclaim myself what I am:
I will now take the Lecher: he is at my house: he
cannot scape me: it is impossible he should: he cannot
creep into a halfpenny purse, nor into a pepper-box:
But least the Devil that guides him, should
aid him, I will search impossible places: though
what I am, I cannot avoid; yet to be what I would
not, shall not make me tame: If I have horns, to make
one mad, let the proverb go with me, I will be horn mad.

div2.stage: Enter Mistris Page, Quickly, William, Euans.

sp.speaker: Mist. Pag.
sp.p: Is he at Mister Fords already thinkst thou?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
Sure he is by this; or will be presently; but
truly he is very conragious mad, about his throwing
into the water. Mistress Ford desires you to come suddenly.

sp.speaker: Mist. Pag.
sp.p:
I will be with her by and by: I will but bring
my young man here to School: look where his Master
comes; it is a playing day I see: how now Sir Hugh, no
School today?

sp.speaker: Eua.
sp.p: No: Master Slender is let the Boys leave to play.

sp.speaker: Qui
sp.p: Blessing of his heart.

sp.speaker: Mist. Pag.
sp.p:
Sir Hugh, my husband says my son profits
nothing in the world at his Book: I pray you ask
him some questions in his Accidence.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Come hither William; hold up your head; come.

sp.speaker: Mist. Pag.
sp.p:
Come on Sirra; hold up your head; answer
your Master, be not afraid.

sp.speaker: Eua.
sp.p: William, how many Numbers is in Nouns?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Two.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
Truly, I thought there had been one Number
more, because they say od's-Nownes.

sp.speaker: Eua.
sp.p: Peace, your tattlings. What is (Fair) William?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Pulcher.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p:
Polecats? there are fairer things than Polecats,
sure.

sp.speaker: Eua.
sp.p:
You are a very simplicity o'man: I pray you
peace. What is (Lapis) William?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: A Stone.

sp.speaker: Eua.
sp.p: And what is a Stone (William?)

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: A Pebble.

sp.speaker: Eua.
sp.p:
No; it is Lapis: I pray you remember in your
brain.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Lapis.

sp.speaker: Eua.
sp.p:
That is a good William: what is he (William) that
does lend Articles.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p:
Articles are borrowed of the Pronoun; and be
thus declined. Singulariter nominatiuo hic hæc,hoc.

sp.speaker: Eua.
sp.p:
Nominatiuo hig, hag, hog: pray you mark: genitive
huius: Well. what is your Accusative-case?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Accusatiuo hinc.

sp.speaker: Eua.
sp.p: I pray you have your remembrance (child) Accusatiuo hing, hang, hog.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: Hang-hog, is latin for Bacon, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Eua.
sp.p:
Leave your parables (o'man) What is the Vocative
case (William?)

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: O, Vocatiuo, O.

sp.speaker: Eua.
sp.p: Remember William, Vocative, is caret.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: And that is a good root.

sp.speaker: Eua.
sp.p: O'man, forbear.

sp.speaker: Mist. Pag.
sp.p: Peace.

sp.speaker: Eua.
sp.p: What is your Genitive case plural (William?)

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Genitive case?

sp.speaker: Eua.
sp.p: Aye.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Genitive horum, harum, horum.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p:
Vengeance of Ginyes case; fie on her; never
name her (child) if she be a whore.

sp.speaker: Eua.
sp.p: For shame o'man.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p:
You do ill to teach the child such words: he
teaches him to hic, and to hac; which they will do fast
enough of themselves, and to call horum; fie upon you.

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p:
O'man, art thou Lunatics? Hast thou no understandings
for thy Cases, and the numbers of the Genders?
Thou art as foolish Christian creatures, as I would
desires.

sp.speaker: Mi. Page.
sp.p: Prithee hold thy peace.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p:
Show me now (William) some declensions of your
Pronouns.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Forsooth, I have forgot.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p:
It is Qui, que, quod; if you forget your Quies,
your Ques, and your Quods, you must be breeches: Go
your ways and play, go.

sp.speaker: M. Pag.
sp.p: He is a better scholar than I thought he was.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: He is a good sprag-memory: Farewell Mistress Page.

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.l: Adieu good Sir Hugh:
Get you home boy, Come we stay too long.

div2.stage:
Enter Falstoffe, Mist. Ford, Mist. Page, Seruants, Ford,
Page, Caius, Euans, Shallow.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Mistress Ford, Your sorrow hath eaten up my sufferance;
I see you are obsequious in your love, and I profess
requital to a hairs breadth, not only Mistress Ford,
in the simple office of love, but in all the accoutrements,
complement, and ceremony of it: But are you sure of
your husband now?

sp.speaker: Mis. Ford.
sp.p: He is a-birding (sweet Sir Iohn.)

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p: What ho, gossip Ford: what ho.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ford.
sp.p: Step into the chamber, Sir Iohn.

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p:
How now (sweet heart) who is at home
besides yourself?

sp.speaker: Mis Ford
sp.p: Why none but mine own people.

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p: Indeed?

sp.speaker: Mis. Ford.
sp.p: No certainly: Speak louder.

sp.speaker: Mist. Pag.
sp.p: Truly, I am so glad you have nobody here.

sp.speaker: Mist. Ford.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Mis Page.
sp.p:
Why woman, your husband is in his old
lines again: he so takes on yonder with my husband, so
rails against all married mankind; so curses all Eves
daughters, of what complexion soever and so buffets
himself on the for-head: crying peere-out, peere-out,
that any madness I ever yet beheld, seemed but tameness,
civility, and patience to this his distemper he is in
now: I am glad the fat Knight is not here.

sp.speaker: Mist. Ford.
sp.p: Why, does he talk of him?

sp.speaker: Mist. Page.
sp.p:
Of none but him, and swears he was carried
out the last time he searched for him, in a Basket:
Protests to my husband he is now here, and hath drawn
him and the rest of their company from their sport, to
make another experiment of his suspicion: But I am glad
the Knight is not here; now he shall see his own foolery.

sp.speaker: Mist. Ford.
sp.p: How near is he Mistress Page?

sp.speaker: Mist. Pag.
sp.p: Hard by, at street end; he will be here anon.

sp.speaker: Mist. Ford.
sp.p: I am undone, the Knight is here.

sp.speaker: Mist. Page.
sp.p:
Why then you are utterly shamed, and he is
but a dead man. What a woman are you? Away with
him, away with him. Better shame, than murther.

sp.speaker: Mist. Ford.
sp.p:
Which way should he go? How should I
bestow him? Shall I put him into the basket again?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: No, I will come no more in the Basket:
May I not go out ere he come?

sp.speaker: Mist. Page.
sp.p:
Alas: three of Mr. Fords brothers watch
the door with Pistols, that none shall issue out: otherwise
you might slip away ere he came: But what make
you here?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: What shall I do? I will creep up into the chimney.

sp.speaker: Mist. Ford.
sp.p:
There they always use to discharge their
Birding-pieces: creep into the Kill-hole.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Where is it?

sp.speaker: Mist. Ford.
sp.p:
He will seek there on my word: Neither
Press, Coffer, Chest, Trunk, Well, Vault, but he hath
an abstract for the remembrance of such places, and goes
to them by his Note: There is no hiding you in the
house.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I will go out then.

sp.speaker: Mist. Ford.
sp.p:
If you go out in your own
semblance,
you die Sir Iohn, unless you go out disguised.

sp.speaker: Mist. Ford.
sp.p: How might we disguise him?

sp.speaker: Mist. Page.
sp.p:
Alas the day I know not, there is no woman's
gown big enough for him: otherwise he might
put on a hat, a muffler, and a kerchief, and so escape.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Good hearts, devise something: any extremity,
rather than a mischief.

sp.speaker: Mist. Ford.
sp.p:
My Maids Aunt the fat woman of Brainford,
has a gown above.

sp.speaker: Mist. Page.
sp.p:
On my word it will serve him: she is as
big as he is: and there is her thrummed hat, and her muffler
too: run up Sir Iohn.

sp.speaker: Mist. Ford.
sp.p:
Go, go, sweet Sir Iohn: Mistress Page and
I will look some linen for your head.

sp.speaker: Mist. Page.
sp.p:
Quick, quick, we will come dress you
straight: put on the gown the while.

sp.speaker: Mist. Ford.
sp.p:
I would my husband would meet him
in this shape: he cannot abide the old woman of Brainford;
he swears she is a witch, forbade her my house, and
hath threatened to beat her.

sp.speaker: Mist. Page.
sp.p:
Heaven guide him to thy husbands cudgel:
and the devil guide his cudgel afterwards.

sp.speaker: Mist. Ford.
sp.p: But is my husband coming?

sp.speaker: Mist. Page.
sp.p:
Aye in good sadness is he, and talks of the
basket too, howsoever he hath had intelligence.

sp.speaker: Mist. Ford.
sp.p:
We will try that: for I will appoint my men to
carry the basket again, to meet him at the door with
it, as they did last time.

sp.speaker: Mist. Page.
sp.p:
Nay, but he will be here presently: let us go
dress him like the witch of Brainford.

sp.speaker: Mist. Ford.
sp.p:
I will first direct direct my men, what they
shall do with the basket: Go up, I will bring linen for
him straight.

sp.speaker: Mist. Page.
sp.l: Hang him dishonest Varlet,
We cannot misuse enough:
We will leave a proof by that which we will do,
Wives may be merry, and yet honest too:
We do not act that often, jest, and laugh,
It is old, but true, Still Swine eats all the draught.

sp.speaker: Mist. Ford.
sp.p:
Go Sirs, take the basket again on your
shoulders: your Master is hard at door: if he bid you
set it down, obey him: quickly, dispatch.

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.p: Come, come, take it up.

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.p: Pray heaven it be not full of Knight again.

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.p: I hope not, I had lief as bear so much lead.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
Aye, but if it prove true (Mr. Page) have you any
way then to unfool me again. Set down the basket
villain: somebody call my wife: Youth in a basket:
O you Panderly Rascals, there is a knot: a gin, a pack,
a conspiracy against me: Now shall the devil be shamed.
What wife I say: Come, come forth: behold what honest
clothes you send forth to bleaching.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Why, this passes Mister Ford: you are not to go
loose any longer, you must be pinioned.

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p:
Why, this is Lunatics: this is mad, as a
mad dog.

sp.speaker: Shall.
sp.p: Indeed Mister Ford, this is not well indeed.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
So say I too Sir, come hither Mistress Ford, Mistress
Ford, the honest woman, the modest wife, the virtuous
creature, that hath the jealous fool to her husband:
I suspect without cause (Mistress) do I?

sp.speaker: Mist. Ford.
sp.p:
Heaven be my witness you do, if you
suspect me in any dishonesty.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
Well said Brazon-face, hold it out: Come forth
sirra.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: This passes.

sp.speaker: Mist. Ford.
sp.p: Are you not ashamed, let the cloths alone.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: I shall find you anon.

sp.speaker: Eua.
sp.p:
It is unreasonable; will you take up your wives
clothes? Come, away.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Empty the basket I say.

sp.speaker: M. Ford.
sp.p: Why man, why?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
Master Page, as I am a man, there was one conveyed
out of my house yesterday in this basket: why
may not he be there again, in my house I am sure he is:
my Intelligence is true, my jealousy is reasonable, pluck
me out all the linen.

sp.speaker: Mist. Ford.
sp.p:
If you find a man there, he shall die a Fleas
death.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Here is no man.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
By my fidelity this is not well Mr. Ford: This
wrongs you.

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p:
Mr Ford, you must pray, and not follow the
imaginations of your own heart: this is jealousies.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Well, he is not here I seek for.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: No, nor nowhere else but in your brain.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
Help to search my house this one time: if I find
not what I seek, show no colour for my extremity: Let
me forever be your Table-sport: Let them say of me, as
jealous as Ford, that searched a hollow Wall-nut for his
wives Leman. Satisfy me once more, once more search
with me.

sp.speaker: M. Ford.
sp.p:
What ho (Mistress Page,) come you and
the old woman down: my husband will come into the
Chamber.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Old woman? what old woman is that?

sp.speaker: M. Ford.
sp.p: Why it is my maids Aunt of Brainford.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
A witch, a Quean, an old cozening quean:
Have I not forbid her my house. She comes of errands
does she? We are simple men, we do not know what is
brought to pass under the profession of Fortune-telling.
She works by Charms, by Spells, by the Figure, and such
dawbry as this is, beyond our Element: we know nothing.
Come down you Witch, you Hag you, come
down I say.

sp.speaker: Mist. Ford.
sp.p:
Nay, good sweet husband, good Gentlemen,
let him strike the old woman.

sp.speaker: Mist. Page.
sp.p:
Come mother Prat, Come give me your
hand.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
I will Prat-her: Out of my door, you Witch,
you Rag, you Baggage, you Polecat, you Runnion,
out, out: I will conjure you, I will fortune-tell you.

sp.speaker: Mist. Page.
sp.p: Are you not ashamed?
I think you have killed the poor woman.

sp.speaker: Mist. Ford.
sp.p:
Nay he will do it, it is a goodly credit
for you.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Hang her witch.

sp.speaker: Eua.
sp.p:
By yea, and no, I think the o'man is a witch indeed:
I like not when a o'man has a great beard; I spy
a great beard under his muffler.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
Will you follow Gentlemen, I beseech you follow:
see but the issue of my jealousy: If I cry out thus
upon no trail, never trust me when I open again.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Let us obey his humour a little further:
Come Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Mist. Page.
sp.p: Trust me he beat him most pitifully.

sp.speaker: Mist. Ford.
sp.p:
Nay by the Mass that he did not: he beat
him most unpitifully, methought.

sp.speaker: Mist. Page.
sp.p:
I will have the cudgel hallowed, and hung
over the Altar, it hath done meritorious service.

sp.speaker: Mist. Ford.
sp.p:
What think you? May we with the warrant
of woman-hood, and the witness of a good conscience,
pursue him with any further revenge?

sp.speaker: M. Page.
sp.p:
The spirit of wantonness is sure scared out
of him, if the devil have him not in fee-simple, with
fine and recovery, he will never (I think) in the way of
waste, attempt us again.

sp.speaker: Mist. Ford.
sp.p:
Shall we tell our husbands how we have
served him?

sp.speaker: Mist. Page
sp.p:
Yes, by all means: if it be but to scrape
the figures out of your husbands brains: if they can find
in their hearts, the poor unvirtuous fat Knight shall be
any further afflicted, we two will still be the ministers.

sp.speaker: Mist. Ford.
sp.p:
I will warrant, they will have him publicly
shamed, and methinks there would be no period to the
jest, should he not be publicly shamed.

sp.speaker: Mist. Page.
sp.p:
Come, to the Forge with it, then shape it:
I would not have things cool.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p:
Sir, the Germane desires to have three of your
horses: the Duke himself will be tomorrow at Court,
and they are going to meet him.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
What Duke should that be comes so secretly?
I hear not of him in the Court: let me speak with the
Gentlemen, they speak English?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Aye Sir? I will call him to you.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
They shall have my horses, but I will make them
pay: I will sauce them, they have had my houses a week at
command: I have turned away my other guests, they
must come off, I will sauce them, come.

div2.stage: Enter Page, Ford, Mistris Page, Mistris Ford, and Euans.

sp.speaker: Eua.
sp.p:
It is one of the best directors of a o'man as ever
I did look upon.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
And did he send you both these Letters at an
instant?

sp.speaker: Mist. Page.
sp.p: Within a quarter of an hour.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Pardon me (wife) henceforth do what you wilt:
I rather will suspect the Sun with gold,
Than thee with wantonness: Now doth thy honour stand
(In him that was of late an Heretic)
As firm as faith.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: It is well, it is well, no more:
Be not as extreme in submission, as in offence,
But let our plot go forward: Let our wives
Yet once again (to make us public sport)
Appoint a meeting with this old fat-fellow,
Where we may take him, and disgrace him for it.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: There is no better way than that they spoke of.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
How? to send him word they will meet him in
the Parke at midnight? Fie, fie, he will never come.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p:
You say he has been thrown in the Rivers: and
has been grievously beaten, as an old o'man: methinks
there should be terrors in him, that he should not come:
methinks his flesh is punished, he shall have no desires.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: So think I too.

sp.speaker: M. Ford.
sp.l: Devise but how you will use him when he comes,
And let us two devise to bring him thither.

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p:
There is an old tale goes, that Herne the
Hunter (sometime a keeper here in Windsor Forest)
sp.l: Doth all the winter time, at still midnight
Walk round about an Oak, with great ragged-horns,
And there he blasts the tree, and takes the cattle,
And make milch-kine yield blood, and shakes a chain
In a most hideous and dreadful manner.
You have heard of such a Spirit, and well you know
The superstitious idle-headed-Eld
Received, and did deliver to our age
This tale of Herne the Hunter, for a truth.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Why yet there want not many that do fear
In deep of night to walk by this Hernes Oak:
But what of this?

sp.speaker: Mist. Ford.
sp.l: Marry this is our devise,
That Falstaffe at that Oak shall meet with us.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Well, let it not be doubted but he will come,
And in this shape, when you have brought him thither,
What shall be done with him? What is your plot?

sp.speaker: Mist. Pa.
sp.l: That likewise have we thought upon: and thus:
Nan Page (my daughter) and my little son,
And three or four more of their growth, we will dress
Like Urchins, Ouphes, and Fairies, green and white,
With rounds of waxen Tapers on their heads,
And rattles in their hands; upon a sudden,
As Falstaffe, she, and I, are newly met,
Let them from forth a saw-pit rush at once
With some diffused song: Upon their sight
We two, in great amazedness will fly:
Then let them all encircle him about,
And Fairy-like to pinch the unclean Knight;
And ask him why that hour of Fairy Revel,
In their so sacred paths, he dares to tread
In shape profane.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: And till he tell the truth,
Let the supposed Fairies pinch him, sound,
And burn him with their Tapers.

sp.speaker: Mist. Page.
sp.l: The truth being known,
We will all present ourselves; dis-horne the spirit,
And mock him home to Windsor.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: The children must
Be practised well to this, or they will never do it.

sp.speaker: Eua.
sp.p:
I will teach the children their behaviours: and I
will be like a Iacke-an-Apes also, to burn the Knight
with my Tabor.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: That will be excellent,
I will go buy them vizards.

sp.speaker: Mist. Page.
sp.p:
My Nan shall be the Queen of all the
Fairies, finely attired in a robe of white.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: That silk will I go buy, and in that time
Shall Mister Slender steal my Nan away,
And marry her at Eaton: go, send to Falstaffe straight.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Nay, I will to him again in name of Broome,
He will tell me all his purpose: sure he will come.

sp.speaker: Mist. Page.
sp.l: Fear not you that: Go get us properties
And tricking for our Fairies.

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.l: Let us about it,
It is admirable pleasures, and very honest knaveries.

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.l: Go Mistress Ford,
Send quickly to Sir Iohn, to know his mind:
I will to the Doctor, he hath my good will,
And none but he to marry with Nan Page:
That Slender (though well landed) is an Idiot:
And he, my husband best of all affects:
The Doctor is well moneyed, and his friends
Potent at Court: he, none but he shall have her,
Though twenty thousand worthier come to crave her.

div2.stage:
Enter Host, Simple, Falstaffe, Bardolfe, Euans,
Caius, Quickly.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
What wouldst thou have? (Boor) what? (thick
skin) speak, breathe, discuss: brief, short, quick,
snap.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p:
Marry Sir, I come to speak with Sir Iohn Falstaffe
from Mister Slender.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
There is his Chamber, his House, his Castle,
his standing-bed and truckle-bed: it is painted about
with the story of the Prodigal, fresh and new: go, knock
and call: he will speak like an Anthropophaginian unto
thee: Knock I say.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p:
There is an old woman, a fat woman gone up
into his chamber: I will be so bold as stay Sir till she come
down: I come to speak with her indeed.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Ha? A fat woman? The Knight may be robbed:
I will call. Bully-Knight, Bully Sir Iohn: speak from thy
Lungs Military: Art thou there? It is thine Host, thine
Ephesian calls.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: How now, mine Host?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Here is a Bohemian-Tartar tarries the coming
down of thy fat-woman: Let her descend (Bully) let
her descend: my Chambers are honourable: Fie, privacy?
Fie.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
There was (mine Host) an old-fat-woman even
now with me, but she is gone.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p:
Pray you Sir, was it not the Wise-woman of
Brainford?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Aye marry was it (Mussel-shell) what would you
with her?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p:
My Master (Sir) my master Slender, sent to her
seeing her go through the streets, to know (Sir) whether
one Nim (Sir) that beguiled him of a chain, had the
chain, or no.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I spake with the old woman about it.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: And what says she, I pray Sir?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Marry she says, that the very same man that
beguiled Master Slender of his Chain, cozened him of it.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p:
I would I could have spoken with the Woman
herself, I had other things to have spoken with her
too, from him.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: What are they? let us know:

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Aye: come: quick.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I may not conceal them (Sir.)

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Conceal them, or thou diest

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p:
Why sir, they were nothing but about Mistress
Anne Page, to know if it were my Masters fortune to
have her, or no.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: It is, it is his fortune.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: What Sir?

sp.speaker: Fal.
Sim.
sp.p: May I be bold to say so Sir?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Aye Sir: like who more bold.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p:
I thank your worship: I shall make my Master
glad with these tidings.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Thou are clerkly: thou art clerkly (Sir Iohn)
was there a wise woman with thee?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Aye that there was (mine Host) one that hath taught
me more wit, than ever I learned before in my life: and
I paid nothing for it neither, but was paid for my learning.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Out alas (Sir) cozenage: mere cozenage.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Where be my horses? speak well of them varletto.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p:
Run away with the cozeners: for so soon as
I came beyond Eaton, they threw me off, from behind
one of them, in a slough of mire; and set spurs, and
away; like three German-devils; three Doctor Faustasses.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
They are gone but to meet the Duke (villain)
do not say they be fled: Germans are honest men.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: Where is mine Host?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: What is the matter Sir?

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p:
Have a care of your entertainments: there is a
friend of mine come to Town, tells me there is three
Cozen-Iermans, that has cozened all the Hosts of Readins,
of Maidenhead; of Cole-brooke, of horses and money: I
tell you for good will (look you) you are wise, and full
of gibes, and flouting-stocks: and it is not convenient
you should be cozened. Fare you well.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: Where is mine Host the Iarteere?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Here (Master Doctor) in perplexity, and doubtful
dilemma.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p:
I cannot tell what is that: but it is tell me, that
you make grand preparation for a Duke de Iamanie: by
my trot: there is no Duke that the Court is know, so
come: I tell you for good will: adieu.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Hue and cry, (villain) go: assist me Knight, I
am undone: fly, run: hue, and cry (villain) I am undone.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
I would all the world might be cozened, for I
have been cozened and beaten too: if it should come
to the ear of the Court, how I have been transformed;
and how my transformation hath been washed, and
cudgeled, they would melt me out of my fat drop by
drop, and liquor Fishermens-boots with me: I warrant
they would whip me with their fine wits, till I were as
crestfallen as a dried pear: I never prospered, since I
forswore myself at Primero: well, if my wind were
but long enough; I would repent: Now? Whence come
you?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: From the two parties forsooth.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
The Devil take one party, and his Dam the
other: and so they shall be both bestowed; I have suffered
more for their sakes; more than the villainous inconstancy
of man's disposition is able to bear.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
And have not they suffered? Yes, I warrant; speciously
one of them; Mistress Ford (good heart) is beaten
black and blue, that you cannot see a white spot about
her.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
What tellest thou me of black, and blue? I
was beaten myself into all the colours of the Rainbow:
and I was like to be apprehended for the Witch
of Braineford, but that my admirable dexterity of wit,
my counterfeiting the action of an old woman delivered
me, the knave Constable had set me in the Stocks, in the common
Stocks, for a Witch.

sp.speaker: Qu,
sp.p:
Sir: let me speak with you in your Chamber,
you shall hear how things go, and (I warrant) to your
content: here is a Letter will say somewhat: (good-hearts)
what ado here is to bring you together? Sure,
one of you does not serve heaven well, that you are so
crossed.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Come up into my Chamber.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Master Fenton, talk not to me, my mind is
heavy: I will give over all.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.l: Yet hear me speak: assist me in my purpose,
And (as I am a gentleman) I will give thee
A hundred pound in gold, more than your loss.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
I will hear you (Master Fenton) and I will (at
the least) keep your counsel.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.l: From time to time, I have acquainted you
With the dear love I bear to fair Anne Page,
Who, mutually, hath answered my affection,
(So far forth, as herself might be her chooser)
Even to my wish; I have a letter from her
Of such contents, as you will wonder at;
The mirth whereof, so larded with my matter,
That neither (singly) can be manifested
Without the show of both: fat Falstaffe
Hath a great Scene; the image of the jest
I will show you here at large (hark good mine Host:)
Tonight at Hernes-Oke, just betwixt twelve and one,
Must my sweet Nan present the Faerie-Queene:
The purpose why, is here: in which disguise
While other Jests are something rank on foot,
Her father hath commanded her to slip
Away with Slender, and with him, at Eaton
Immediately to Marry: She hath consented: Now Sir,
Her Mother, (even strong against that match
And firm for Doctor Caius) hath appointed
That he shall likewise shuffle her away,
While other sports are tasking of their minds,
And at the Deanery, where a Priest attends
Strait marry her: to this her Mothers plot
She seemingly obedient) likewise hath
Made promise to the Doctor: Now, thus it rests,
Her Father means she shall be all in white;
And in that habit, when Slender sees his time
To take her by the hand, and bid her go,
She shall go with him: her Mother hath intended
(The better to devote her to the Doctor:
For they must all be masked, and vizarded)
That quaint in green, she shall be loose enrobed,
With Ribonds-pendant, flaring about her head;
And when the Doctor spies his vantage ripe,
To pinch her by the hand, and on that token,
The maid hath given consent to go with him.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Which means she to deceive? Father, or Mother.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.l: Both (my good Host) to go along with me:
And here it rests, that you will procure the Vicar
To stay for me at Church, betwixt twelve, and one,
And in the lawful name of marrying,
To give our hearts united ceremony.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: Well, husband your device; I will to the Vicar,
Bring you the Maid, you shall not lack a Priest.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.l: So shall I evermore be bound to thee;
Besides, I will make a present recompense.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Prithee no more prattling: go, I will hold, this is
the third time: I hope good luck lies in odd numbers:
Away, go, they say there is Divinity in odd Numbers,
either in nativity, chance, or death: away.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
I will provide you a chain, and I will do what I can
to get you a pair of horns.

sp.speaker: Fall.
sp.p:
Away I say, time wears, hold up your head and
mince. How now Master Broome? Master Broome, the matter
will be known tonight, or never. Be you in the
Parke about midnight, at Hernes-Oake, and you shall
see wonders.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
Went you not to her yesterday (Sir) as you told
me you had appointed?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
I went to her (Master Broome) as you see, like a
poor old man, but I came from her (Master Broome)
like a poor old woman; that same knave (Ford her husband)
hath the finest mad devil of jealousy in him (Master
Broome) that ever governed Frenzy. I will tell you,
he beat me grievously, in the shape of a woman: (for in
the shape of Man (Master Broome) I fear not Goliah
with a Weavers beam, because I know also, life is a
Shuttle) I am in hast, go along with me, I will tell you all
(Master Broome:) since I plucked Geese, played Truant,
and whipped Top, I knew not what it was to be beaten, till
lately. Follow me, I will tell you strange things of this
knave Ford, on whom tonight I will be revenged, and I
will deliver his wife into your hand. Follow, strange
things in hand (Master Broome) follow.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Come, come: we will couch in the Castle-ditch,
till we see the light of our Fairies. Remember son Slender,
my

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
Aye forsooth, I have spoke with her, and we have
a nay-word, how to know one another. I come to her
in white, and cry Mum; she cries Budget, and by that
we know one another.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p:
That is good too: But what needs either your
Mum, or her Budget? The white will decipher her well
enough. It hath struck ten o'clock.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
The night is dark, Light and Spirits will become
it well: Heaven prosper our sport. No man means
evil but the devil, and we shall know him by his horns.
Let us away: follow me.

div2.stage: Enter Mist. Page, Mist. Ford, Caius.

sp.speaker: Mist. Page.
sp.p:
Mr Doctor, my daughter is in green, when
you see your time, take her by the hand, away with her
to the Deanery, and dispatch it quickly: go before into
the Parke: we two must go together.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: I know what I have to do, adieu.

sp.speaker: Mist. Page.
sp.p:
Fare you well (Sir.) my husband will not
rejoice so much at the abuse of Falstaffe, as he will chafe
at the Doctors marrying my daughter: But it is no matter;
better a little chiding, than a great deal of heart-break.

sp.speaker: Mist. Ford.
sp.p:
Where is Nan now? and her troop of Fairies?
and the Welch-deuill Herne?

sp.speaker: Mist. Page.
sp.p:
They are all couched in a pit hard by Hernes
Oak, with obscured Lights; which at the very instant
of Falstaffes and our meeting, they will at once display to
the night.

sp.speaker: Mist. Ford.
sp.p: That cannot choose but amaze him.

sp.speaker: Mist. Page.
sp.p:
If he be not amazed he will be mocked: If
he be amazed, he will every way be mocked.

sp.speaker: Mist. Ford.
sp.p: We will betray him finely.

sp.speaker: Mist. Page.
sp.l: Against such Lewdsters, and their lechery,
Those that betray them, do no treachery.

sp.speaker: Mist. Ford.
sp.p:
The hour drawes on: to the Oak, to the
Oak.

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p:
Trip, Trip Fairies: Come, and remember your
parts: be bold (I pray you) follow me into the pit, and
when I give the watchwords, do as I bid you: Come,
come, Trip, Trip.

div2.stage:
Enter Falstaffe, Mistris Page, Mistris Ford, Euans,
Anne Page, Fairies, Page, Ford, Quickly,
Slender, Fenton, Caius, Pistoll.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
The Windsor-bell hath stroke twelve: the Minute
drawes on: Now the hot-bloodied-Gods assist me:
Remember Jove, thou wast a Bull for thy Europa, Love
set on thy horns. O powerful Love, that in some respects
makes a Beast a Man: in some other, a Man a beast.
You were also (Iupiter) a Swan, for the love of Leda: O
omnipotent Love, how near the God drew to the complexion
of a Goose: a fault done first in the form of a
beast, (O Jove, a beastly fault:) and then another fault,
in the semblance of a Fowl, think on it (Jove) a foul-fault.
When Gods have hot backs, what shall poor
men do? For me, I am here a Windsor Stag, and the
fattest (I think) in the Forest. Send me a cool rut-time
(Jove) or who can blame me to piss my Tallow? Who
comes here? my Doe?

sp.speaker: M. Ford.
sp.p: Sir Iohn? Art thou there (my Dear?)
My male-deer?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
My Doe, with the black Scut? Let the sky
rain Potatoes: let it thunder, to the tune of Green-sleeves,
hail-kissing Comfits, and snow Eryngoes: Let
there come a tempest of provocation, I will shelter me
here.

sp.speaker: M. Ford.
sp.p: Mistress Page is come with me (sweet heart.)

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Divide me like a brib'd-Bucke, each a Haunch:
I will keep my sides to myself, my shoulders for the
fellow of this walk; and my horns I bequeath your
husbands. Am I a Woodman, ha? Speak I like Herne
the Hunter? Why, now is Cupid a child of conscience,
he makes restitution. As I am a true spirit, welcome.

sp.speaker: M. Page.
sp.p: Alas, what noise?

sp.speaker: M. Ford.
sp.p: Heaven forgive our sins.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: What should this be?

sp.speaker: M. Ford. M. Page
sp.p: Away, away.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: I think the devil will not have me damned,
Lest the oil that is in me should set hell on fire;
He would never else cross me thus.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Fairies black, gray, green, and white,
You Moonshine revellers, and shades of night.
You Orphan heirs of fixed destiny,
Attend your office, and your quality.
Crier Hobgoblin, make the Fairy Oyes.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: Elves, list your names: Silence you airy toys.
Cricket, to Windsor-chimnies shalt thou leap;
Where fires thou findest unraked, and hearths unswept,
There pinch the Maids as blue as Bill-berry,
Our radiant Queen, hates Sluts, and Sluttery.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: They are Fairies, he that speaks to them shall die,
I will wink, and couch: No man their works must eye.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Where is Bede? Go you, and where you find a maid
That ere she sleep has thrice her prayers said,
Raise up the Organs of her fantasy,
Sleep she as sound as careless infancy,
But those as sleep, and think not on their sins,
Pinch them arms, legs, backs, shoulders, sides, and shins.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: About, about:
Search Windsor Castle (Elves) within, and out.
Strew good luck (Ouphes) on every sacred room,
That it may stand till the perpetual doom,
In state as wholesome, as in state it is fit,
Worthy the Owner, and the Owner it.
The several Chairs of Order, look you scour
With juice of Balm; and every precious flower,
Each fair Instalment, Coat, and several Crest,
With loyal Blazon, evermore be blessed.
And Nightly-meadow-Fairies, look you sing
Like to the Garters-Compasse, in a ring,
The expressure that it bears: Green let it be,
More fertile-fresh than all the Field to see:
And, Hony Soit Qui Mal-y-Pence, write
In Emrold-tuffes, Flowers purple, blue, and white,
Like Sapphire-pearl, and rich embroidery,
Buckled below fair Knight-hoods bending knee;
Fairies use Flowers for their characterie.
Away, disperse: But till it is one o'clock,
Our Dance of Custom, round about the Oak
Of Herne the Hunter, let us not forget.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.l: Pray you lock hand in hand: yourselves in order set:
And twenty glowworms shall our Lanterns be
To guide our Measure round about the Tree.
But stay, I smell a man of middle earth.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.l: Heavens defend me from that Welsh Fairy,
Least he transform me to a piece of Cheese.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p:
Vile worm, thou wast overlooked even in thy
birth.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: With Trial-fire touch me his finger end:
If he be chaste, the flame will back descend
And turn him to no pain: but if he start,
It is the flesh of a corrupted heart.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.l: A trial, come.

sp.speaker: Eua.
sp.l: Come: will this wood take fire?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: O, o, o.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.l: Corrupt, corrupt, and tainted in desire.
About him (Fairies) sing a scornful rime,
And as you trip, still pinch him to your time.
Fie on sinful fantasy: Fie on Lust, and Luxury:
Lust is but a bloody fire, kindled with unchaste desire,
Fed in heart whose flames aspire,
As thoughts do blow them higher and higher.
Pinch him (Fairies) mutually: Pinch him for his villainy.
Pinch him, and burn him, and turn him about,
Till Candles, and Star-light, and Moonshine be out.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Nay do not fly, I think we have watched you
now: Will none but Herne the Hunter serve your
turn?

sp.speaker: M. Page.
sp.l: I pray you come, hold up the jest no higher.
Now (good Sir Iohn) how like you Windsor wives?
See you these husband? Do not these fair yokes
Become the Forest better than the Town?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Now Sir, who is a Cuckold now?
Mr Broome, Falstaff is a Knave, a Cuckoldly knave,
Here are his horns Master Broomes:
sp.p:
And Master Broome, he hath enjoyed nothing of Fords,
but his Buck-basket, his cudgel, and twenty pounds of
money, which must be paid to Mr Broome, his horses are
arrested for it, Mr Broome.

sp.speaker: M. Ford.
sp.p:
Sir Iohn, we have had ill luck: we could
never meet: I will never take you for my Love again,
but I will always count you my Dear.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I do begin to perceive that I am made an Ass.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Aye, and an Ox too: both the proofs are extant.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: And these are not Fairies:

I was three or four times in the thought they were not
Fairies, and yet the guiltiness of my mind, the sudden
surprise of my powers, drove the grossness of the foppery
into a received belief, in despite of the teeth of
all rime and reason, that they were Fairies. See now
how wit may be made a Iacke-a-Lent, when it is upon ill
employment.

sp.speaker: Euant.
sp.p:
Sir John Falstaffe, serve God, and leave your
desires, and Fairies will not pinse you.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Well said Fairy Hugh.

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p:
And leave you your jealousies too, I pray
you.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
I will never mistrust my wife again, till thou
art able to woo her in good English.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Have I laid my brain in the Sun, and dried it,
that it wants matter to prevent so gross over-reaching as
this? Am I ridden with a Welsh Goat too? Shall I have
a Coxcomb of Prize? It is time I were choked with a
piece of toasted Cheese.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p:
Cheese is not good to give butter; your belly is all butter
.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Cheese, and Butter? Have I lived to stand at the
taunt of one that makes Fritters of English? This is enough
to be the decay of lust and late-walking through
the Realm.

sp.speaker: Mist. Page.
sp.p:
Why Sir Iohn, do you think though we
would have thrust virtue out of our hearts by the head
and shoulders, and have given ourselves without scruple
to hell, that ever the devil could have made you our
delight?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: What, a hodge-pudding? A bag of flax?

sp.speaker: Mist. Page.
sp.p: A puffed man?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Old, cold, withered, and of intolerable entrails?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: And one that is as slanderous as Satan?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: And as poor as Iob?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: And as wicked as his wife?

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p:
And given to Fornications, and to Taverns,
and Sack, and Wine, and Metheglins, and to drinkings
and swearing, and starings? Pribles and prables?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Well, I am your Theme: you have the start of
me, I am dejected: I am not able to answer the Welsh
Flannel, Ignorance itself is a plummet over me, use me
as you will.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
Marry Sir, we will bring you to Windsor to one
Mr Broome, that you have cozened of money, to whom
you should have been a Pander: over and above that you
have suffered, I think, to repay that money will be a biting
affliction.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Yet be cheerful Knight: thou shalt eat a posset
tonight at my house, where I will desire thee to laugh
at my wife, that now laughs at thee: Tell her Mr Slender
hath married her daughter.

sp.speaker: Mist. Page.
sp.p: Doctors doubt that;

If Anne Page be my daughter, she is (by this) Doctor
Caius wife.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Whoa ho, ho, Father Page.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Son? How now? How now Son,
Have you despatched?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
Despatched? I will make the best in Glostershire
know on it: would I were hanged la, else.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Of what son?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
I came yonder at Eaton to marry Mistress Anne
Page, and she is a great lubberly boy. If it had not been
in the Church, I would have swinged him, or he should
have swinged me. If I did not think it had been Anne
Page, would I might never stir, and it is a Post-masters
Boy.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Upon my life then, you took the wrong.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
What need you tell me that? I think so, when
I took a Boy for a Girl: If I had been married to him,
(for all he was in woman's apparel) I would not have
had him.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Why this is your own folly,
Did not I tell you how you should know my daughter,
By her garments?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p:
I went to her in green, and cried Mum, and
she cried budget, as Anne and I had appointed, and yet
it was not Anne, but a Post-masters boy.

sp.speaker: Mist. Page.
sp.p:
Good George be not angry, I knew of
your purpose: turned my daughter into white, and indeed
she is now with the Doctor at the Deanery, and
there married.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p:
Where is Mistress Page: by-gar I am cozened, I have
married a Garcon, a boy; a peasant, by-gar. A boy,
it is not Anne Page, by-gar, I am cozened.

sp.speaker: M. Page.
sp.p: Why? did you take her in white?

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p:
I by-gar, and it is a boy: by-gar, I will raise all
Windsor.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: This is strange: Who hath got the right Anne?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: My heart misgives me, here comes Mr Fenton.
How now Mr Fenton?

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.p: Pardon good father, good my mother pardon

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: Now Mistress:
How chance you went not with Mr Slender?

sp.speaker: M. Page.
sp.l: Why went you not with Mr Doctor, maid?

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.l: You do amaze her: hear the truth of it,
You would have married her most shamefully,
Where there was no proportion held in love:
The truth is, she and I (long since contracted)
Are now so sure that nothing can dissolve us:
The offence is holy, that she hath committed,
And this deceit looses the name of craft,
Of disobedience, or unduteous title,
Since therein she doth evitate and shun
A thousand irreligious cursed hours
Which forced marriage would have brought upon her.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Stand not amazed, here is no remedy:
In Love, the heavens themselves do guide the state,
Money buys Lands, and wives are sold by fate.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
I am glad, though you have taken a special stand
to strike at me, that your Arrow hath glanced.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Well, what remedy? Fenton, heaven give thee
joy, what cannot be eschewed, must be embraced.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
When night-dogs run, all sorts of Dear are
chased.

sp.speaker: Mist. Page.
sp.l: Well, I will muse no further: Mr Fenton,
Heaven give you many, many merry days:
Good husband, let us everyone go home,
And laugh this sport over by a Country fire,
Sir Iohn and all.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.l: Let it be so (Sir Iohn:)
To Master Broome, you yet shall hold your word,
For he, tonight, shall lie with Mistress Ford:
